item.title: April 22: 30 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: Launch actions, not just apps. It's like speed dial for everyday tasks. Launch Center Pro saves you time by launching complex actions in a single tap.

02  Alibaba: They have a service called Taobao that's a combination of eBay and Amazon, but twice as big as those two Western services combined. Here's a list of 10 "weird" things you can find on it. Semi-Spoiler: Scorpions, soap made out of breast milk, boyfriends, poetry.

03  Amazon: In most U.S. states, people don't pay tax for goods purchased online. In some states, they do. Researchers have discovered "in states that have the [online] tax, households reduced their spending on Amazon by about 10% compared to those in states that don't have the levy. For online purchases of more than $300, sales fell by 24%."

04  Amazon: The newly announced Fire TV will be able to search Netflix's catalog via voice "later this year" according to Netflix CEO Reed Hastings.

05  Apple: MacRumors has discovered that Apple is expanding the definition of the company's trademark to include jewelry.

06  Apple: Re/code says Apple is interviewing people who will be tasked with "[building] an electronic payments business" that will make use of the 600+ million credit cards the company has on file. No word as to who is being interviewed, what the service will actually provide, or when it will launch.

07  Apple: They uploaded two new videos. One champions how green Apple is, the other is about Apple's upcoming "spaceship" campus. The former is getting a lot of attention because Tim Cook, Apple's CEO, did the narration. Both come off as boring to me, but that doesn't really matter, because I don't buy Apple hardware based on the quality of the company's commercials.

08  AT&T: They won't admit it, but because of Google Fiber, AT&T published a list yesterday of 100 cities that may or may not eventually get "GigaPower" (read: one gigabit per second) internet access. No word as to how much the service will actually cost.

09  Beats: This Spotify competitor (read: clone) is "in the process of closing a new round valued between $60 million and $100 million." It's also said that Beats allegedly has a "low six figure" number of paying subscribers.

10  Google: They've updated their chat app, Hangouts, to finally show text messages and chat messages from the same individual in one window. Previously, text messages (SMS) and instant messages (OTT) to the same person were considered different conversations.

11  Google: VentureBeat is reporting that Google is working on making PGP encryption drop dead simple to use with Gmail. No word as to when this research will transform into an actual product. Also, doesn't Google need to scan your email to serve you ads?

12  HTC: They announced a new budget 4.0 inch phone called the Desire 210. It's powered by a MediaTek processor and will cost roughly $145 when it launches in India next month.

13  LG: They published three new pieces of information about the upcoming G Watch, the first device to be powered by Android Wear. There will be a "champagne gold" color option, the screen will always be on, and it's dust and water resistant. Note that earlier this month, LG told the UK publication Pocket-lint that the G Watch would hit the market before July at a price of less than £180 ($300).

14  Microsoft: They published a blog post saying the Nokia deal will close this Friday (25th).

15  Motorola Solutions: Not to be confused with Motorola Mobility, which Google bought and then sold, Motorola Solutions has just signed a licensing agreement with Microsoft over patents relating to Android and Chrome OS.

16  Netflix: The company reported their financial results yesterday. All you need to know is that they now have 48 million subscribers and they're planning to charge $1 to $2 more for the service later this year, but only for new customers in certain unspecified countries. Netflix CEO Reed Hastings was keen to point out that HBO has 130 million subscribers, and he's "eager to close the gap".

17  Target: Best thought of as a premium version of Walmart, Target is now offering 1,500 items via an online "subscription" service. In other words, you tell Target you want a bottle of shampoo and conditioner sent to your house once a month, and they'll deliver.

18  VKontakte: Russia's version of Facebook was just stolen from the CEO by people that aren't technically from the Russian government, but they may as well be.

19  Yahoo!: You know how when you Google certain things, a box appears on the righthand side with a specific answer to your query? Yahoo! is testing a clone of that.

The Real World

20  China: Robots are used by companies to minimize the number of people they need to employ in their factories. This small restaurant is using that same thinking with their robotic chefs and waiters. Cute 82 second video.

21  China: Shandong Airlines just dropped $4.6 billion on 50 Boeing 737 jets.

22  Greece: Yesterday, I shared a video showing two Greek churches celebrating Easter by firing rockets at each other. Today, The Atlantic published 26 photos of the event, and they're stunning.

23  North Korea: South Korea is reporting that a lot of unusual activity is taking place in and around North Korea's nuclear test site. They say North Korea is either going to set something off or want to look like they're going to set something off.

24  South Korea: The latest numbers from the ferry disaster: 104 dead, 198 missing, 174 rescued.

25  Spain: Wind energy generated as much electricity as nuclear energy for the first time in Spain in 2013; 49.1% of the country's electricity now comes from renewables (wind, solar (photovoltaic and thermal) and hydro).

26  Ukraine: Now that Crimea is a part of Russia, what happens next? Putin wants to turn it into Las Vegas.

27  Ukraine: The U.S. State Department has published photos of some of the soldiers fighting in Ukraine, claiming that several of the men are known to be Russian Special Forces. Russia continues to say they're not participating in the Ukrainian conflict.

28  USA: Siale Angilau, age 25, was shot and killed in a courtroom in Utah after he "lunged" at a witness testifying against him. His daughter, who was there, says at least six shots were fired. Question: Why wasn't he restrained in the first place?

29  World: Novartis and GlaxoSmithKline, two of the world's biggest drug makers, are going to combine, kind of. The structure of the deal is a little complicated, but all you need to know is that the two companies will merge their respective consumer health divisions.

30  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: April 21: 44 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: Launch actions, not just apps. It's like speed dial for everyday tasks. Launch Center Pro saves you time by launching complex actions in a single tap.

02  Site News: I have two announcements to make. Number One: Starting today, Tab Dump links will open in a new window. I've lost count of the number of emails I've received asking me to add this "feature". While I personally don't get it, I can't argue with people's wants and desires. Number Two: Naveen Naushad is a huge Tab Dump fan, so much so that he's written an Android app for you guys called "Tab Dumper". It's now in the Play Store, so make sure to check it out!

03  Alibaba: Starting in June, Alibaba, which makes Amazon and eBay look tiny in comparison, will become a wireless operator. They're not going to build a network, however, instead they'll operate an MVNO that uses all three of China's wireless networks.

04  Amazon: Impressive data point of the day: "Every man, woman, and child in Britain spends an average of more than £70 ($120) a year on Amazon."

05  Apple: According to the WSJ, Apple allegedly negotiated deals with gaming companies so that their titles would receive prominent App Store placement in exchange for platform exclusivity. Examples cited: "Plants vs. Zombies 2" stayed exclusive to iOS for two months. "Cut the Rope 2" stayed iOS exclusive for three months.

06  Apple: They recently hired Divya Nag, who 9to5Mac describes as "a rising star in the medical device community". No word as to what she'll actually do at the company, but it's said she's joined Apple's "Medical Technology Team".

07  Beats: This Spotify competitor is in the press because they've decided to start selling subscriptions to their service inside their iOS app. That means they're giving 30% of their revenues to Apple. Rhapsody and Rdio also do this, but Spotify, arguably the King of the Hill, does not.

08  BlackBerry: In an interview with USA Today, the CEO of BlackBerry revealed that a "BlackBerry Classic" QWERTY smartphone will come out in November.

09  Coolpad: You've probably never heard of this company, but they're China's third biggest smartphone maker, and they're not that far behind Lenovo (1% difference in market share). They raised $175 million on Friday.

10  DigiTimes: According to DisplaySearch, 2014 will be the first year where revenues generated from the sale of mobile display panels (phones, tablets, laptops) will surpass revenues generated from television panels.

11  DigiTimes: Apple was responsible for 47.77% of Foxconn's revenues in 2012. Last year, that number went up to 50.63%.

12  DigiTimes: Buried in this article about alternative uses for displays was this interesting data point: "Samsung said 55% of a 5.7-inch AMOLED panel's costs are for materials and components while the percentage is 81% for 55-inch LCD panels." In other words, AMOLED panels are still priced high in order to recuperate R&D costs.

13  DigiTimes: HTC will allegedly make the next Nexus tablet, not ASUS, and it'll have an 8.0 inch panel.

14  Facebook: Re/code says that Facebook will announce a mobile ad network at their F8 conference later this month.

15  Facebook: They've confirmed to TechCrunch that the recently launched "Nearby Friends" feature will be used to serve advertising "in the future". No further details were mentioned.

16  Facebook: They've updated Paper (remember Paper?) with enough new features that it's almost reached parity with the original Facebook app. And yes, it's still iOS only.

17  Google: A rumor with some incredibly sketchy sourcing is being passed around the internet like wildfire. It says Google will unveil a $100 Nexus device this year powered by a MediaTek processor. Strong skepticism urged.

18  Google: Some shady developer wrote an anti-virus app that did absolutely nothing, yet more than 10,000 people spent $3.99 on it. Google's decided to not only refund everyone their money, but also give them $5 of Google Play Store credit.

19  HTC: Buried in this WSJ article on HTC's co-founder is this data point: "When last year's model of the One was released, it sold about 5 million phones in its first two months, compared with 20 million for Samsung's Galaxy S4."

20  HTC: The Google Play Edition version of HTC's flagship phone, the M8, has launched in India. This is the first time a Google Play Edition device has launched outside the United States. What is a GPE device? It's a phone that runs stock Android instead of the custom software the device maker wrote.

21  Journalism: "Print advertising at the nation's newspapers fell 8.6% to $17.3 billion in 2013, according to statistics released today by the Newspaper Association of America." To put some perspective on that $17.3 billion figure, print ads peaked in 2005 at $47.4 billion.

22  LinkedIn: They now have 300 million users; 100 million are in the United States.

23  Microsoft: They're going to build a $1.13 billion data center in Des Moines, Iowa. It'll take four to five years to complete.

24  Microsoft: They're going to open 11 "Specialty Stores" across the U.S. next month. Translation: Mall kiosks.

25  Motorola: Rumor has it that Motorola will launch a 4.3 inch smartphone during the next few weeks called the "Moto E". Unlike the Moto G and Moto X, the Moto E will allegedly have a microSD card slot.

26  Nike: During the weekend, CNET published an article saying Nike wants to kill its smartwatch division because they don't want to compete with Apple's upcoming iWatch. Re/code says that's not what they're hearing. Some people have been let go, yes, but the company is still debating what to do with their FuelBand product.

27  Obi Mobiles: Former Apple CEO John Sculley has launched a new smartphone brand in India: Obi. They haven't really announced anything other than the company logo, and that $20 million will be invested this year to build a supply chain.

28  Samsung: On Sunday, one of Samsung's buildings in Korea caught on fire. No one was hurt, thankfully, but said fire caused Samsung's website to go down and error messages to start appearing on Samsung phones, tablets, and televisions. This brings up a serious question: Is one data center powering all of Samsung's services?

29  Samsung: Remember that free music streaming service Samsung launched back in March? According to the WSJ, it's been downloaded 380,000 times. A premium version will come "soon", though no price and feature list was mentioned.

30  Samsung: The company accidentally published an infographic saying that they'll offer a premium $3.99 per month tier for their music service, Samsung Milk. Other than being "ad-free", it's not yet known what else that $3.99 gets you.

31  Television: The BBC has written an article that explains why various online video streaming services are creating their own television programs. Spoiler: People are not stupid, they prefer shows that feature a story arc that lasts longer than one episode.

32  UK: According to a survey of 7,500 teachers, over 20% of them say they've been harassed via social media. Shockingly, 27% of the negative online comments are from parents, not students.

33  USA: According to an article from the Financial Times that's behind a paywall, Comcast and Time Warner Cable are thinking about giving five million of their subscribers to Charter in order to receive permission to merge.

The Real World

34  China: The country's Environmental Protection Ministry published a report on Friday that says "16.1% of China's soil and 19.4% of its arable land [shows] contamination." Samples from roughly two-thirds of China's land area were captured between 2005 and 2013, so it's safe to say this data is accurate, and disturbing.

35  Greece: This 85 second video shows how two churches on the Greek island of Chios celebrate Easter in their own peculiar way. Spoiler: They launch rockets at each other. The goal is to hit the other church's bell.

36  Netherlands: An unnamed 35 year old man has just been charged with "extortion, internet luring, criminal harassment, and child pornography." Why? Because in In 2012, Amanda Todd, a 15 year old Canadian girl, killed herself after being blackmailed by this sick bastard. He befriended her, asked her to perform sexual acts in front of her webcam, and then used said material to control her.

37  Pakistan: One of the schools in the country's capital has decided to name their library after Osama Bin Laden, calling him both a "martyr" and a "hero". The local government is not happy about this, because it (obviously) sends the world the wrong message about Islam.

38  South Korea: Lee Joon-seok, age 69, was the captain of the ferry that sank. He's officially been arrested and "faces charges including negligence of duty and violation of maritime law."

39  South Korea: The latest numbers from the ferry disaster: 64 dead, 238 missing, 174 rescued.

40  UK: In the mid-1970s, roughly 1,800 people developed malignant melanoma every year. Today, the number is closer to 13,000. Putting those figures another way: In the mid-1970s, three out of every 100,000 people in Britain were diagnosed with malignant melanoma. Today, it's 17 out of every 100,000 people. Cheap holidays to Southern Europe and tan bed abuse are being blamed.

41  USA: Kraft is recalling 96,000 pounds (43,545 kilograms) of hotdogs. They're not dangerous, they're simply mislabeled as "Classic Wieners" instead of "Cheese Dogs". Word of advice: Buy hotdogs from your local butcher. They're guaranteed to taste a million times better.

42  USA: SpaceX successfully launched two tons of supplies and food to the International Space Station on Friday. This is their third mission in conjunction with NASA. Only reason I'm putting this story on Tab Dump is because I love watching rockets take off, so be sure to watch the video.

43  Venezuela: According to the Venezuelan Plastic Surgeons Association, 30% of women between the ages of 18 and 50 are paying people to inject silicone into their butts, despite the fact the government banned the dangerous procedure in 2006.

44  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: April 18: 40 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  This spot is reserved for sponsors. If you want more details, send me an email.

02  Amazon: One of the key selling points of Amazon's new set top box is voice search. Unfortunately, said feature only searches videos offered by Amazon. That will change "this summer" with Hulu Plus, Crackle, and Showtime adding support. Netflix, however, is still missing.

03  Apple: Different car makers are implementing CarPlay in different ways. This two and a half minute video from The Verge shows several of those variations, including one that doesn't even use a touch screen.

04  Apple: They've finally started selling refurbished iPad mini Retina units. The 16 GB model is $339, which is $60 cheaper than a new device. A good friend of mine never buys new Apple equipment, only refurbished stock, and I've never heard him complain.

05  Dropbox: They bought two companies yesterday. The first is Loom. They have seven employees and make a photo management app for iOS and Mac users. The second is Hackpad, which TechCrunch calls "a lightweight, document-collaboration web and mobile application." No financial figures were disclosed.

06  Facebook: They launched a new feature for their Android and iOS apps that allows you to see if your friends are nearby. What's great about this news isn't the feature itself, but how it was presented. Facebook went out of their way to emphasize, repeatedly, that this is optional and fully opt-in.

07  Flickr: They've launched a completely redesigned app for Android and iOS. Spoiler: It looks like Instagram, but with a dark theme.

08  Google: They're now sending people dummy Google Glass units so they can try them on before forking over $1,500. When you order the dummy units, Google puts a $50 hold on your credit card, which is released once you return the glasses.

09  HTC: According to Bloomberg, HTC has "hired the former head of marketing at Samsung Electronics' U.S. mobile phone business as an adviser to Chairman Cher Wang." His name is Paul Golden, and on his LinkedIn profile, he says he "created and launched the highly successful Galaxy brand for Samsung." Marketing is one of HTC's biggest weaknesses, so this is rather exciting.

10  LINE: My favorite chat app has launched a sticker store that enables people to sell their own stickers. The company will take a 50% cut, and while the store only works in Indonesia, Japan, Taiwan, and Thailand at the moment, there are plans to expand.

11  Microsoft: Yesterday, Sony said they sold seven million PS4 consoles. Today, Microsoft is saying they've sold five million XBOX One units.

12  Netflix: According to Bloomberg, they're talking to Vodafone, the world's second largest wireless operator, about a bundling deal. This isn't exactly a new concept. For example, Vodafone UK will gladly offer you a mobile phone contract that includes "free" access to Spotify Premium.

13  Nokia: If you bought a Nokia Lumia 2520 tablet, what's wrong with you? No, but seriously, the company is issuing a recall over the charger. The plastic cap covering the metal contacts can fall off, and if you touch a piece of metal that's plugged into the wall, you know what happens next. Note this impacts roughly 30,000 chargers, so is that how many of these tablets were sold in total?

14  Samsung: In an effort to compete with (and piss off) TSMC, they're going to license their newest chip making technology to GlobalFoundries. More importantly, Samsung says they expect to begin "mass production of foundry chips using 14 nanometer FinFET technology in the fourth quarter." Today's top of the line smartphone chips use 28 nanometer technology. Qualcomm recently announced 20 nanometer chips, but they're not shipping until 2015.

15  Tencent: Fast Company has published what many people are calling the definitive article on Tencent, China's largest internet company. I haven't read the article yet because it's incredibly long, but I plan to during the weekend.

16  Twitter: According to Turkish Communications Minister Lütfi Elvan, Twitter has deleted over 200 tweets, per request of Turkish authorities.

17  Twitter: They've launched two ad products. The first, ads in the Twitter app that point to other apps. Some of you might have already seen them. And the second, a generic mobile ad network powered by last year's MoPub acquisition (allegedly for $350 million).

18  USA: Yesterday, AT&T threatened to not participate in the FCC's 2015 spectrum auction if there were rules in place limiting how much spectrum they could buy. Today, the Head of the FCC, Tom Wheeler, said he doesn't care.

19  Weibo: China's version of Twitter went public on the Nasdaq stock exchange yesterday. Their share price went up almost 20% by the end of the day.

The Real World

20  Belgium: The brains of 21 art students and 23 regular people were scanned and compared. Turns out artists have "significantly more grey matter in an area of the brain called the precuneus in the parietal lobe." Translation: Artists have better motor skills.

21  Brazil: Scientists have discovered insects with confusing genital characteristics. The women have "penises" called "gynosomes" that they stick into male "vaginas" which are said to hold sperm. But the most impressive discovery, to me at least, is that these insects have sex for 70 hours at a time.

22  India: A Delhi surgeon has just reported that he has successfully removed 12 bars of gold, weighing almost 400 grams total, from a man's stomach. That's certainly one way to hide it.

23  Iran: They agreed to cut their supply of enriched uranium by half earlier this year, and they've complied, so the United States is unfreezing Iranian funds worth roughly $450 million.

24  South Korea: The latest numbers on the ferry disaster: 26 people dead. 179 people rescued. 270 still missing.

25  Space: Kepler 186f is being described by scientists as the "most Earth-like planet yet". It's roughly 10% larger than our planet, it's 500 light years away, it has an orbit of roughly 130 days, and it's believed to be a rocky planet that may hold water.

26  UK: The King's College of London has been tracking 7,771 children since 1958 to study the effects of bullying. Their data shows those who were frequently bullied at a young age never really recover from the harassment. They often face depression, anxiety, and even have suicidal thoughts. Bullied children also end up turning into less educated adults, and thus earn less.

27  UK: Where's the best place to put all the CO2 that your coal burning power planet spits out? Under the ground, of course. The White Rose carbon capture and storage (CCS) project will be awarded $415 million in June by the European Union. Once complete, said plant will be able to power 630,000 homes, and 90% of the CO2 it outputs (two million tons a year!) will be stored in undersea rock formations.

28  Ukraine: The Atlantic has published 36 photos of the latest events in Ukraine. Some are quite graphic.

29  Ukraine: There are 11 cities in Ukraine that want to pull a Crimea. Not one, not two, but 11. This two and a half minute video features interviews with the locals, who are screaming from the top of their lungs that they want to be Russian.

30  Ukraine: You've probably read about the "successful" talks in Geneva regarding the Ukrainian situation. Well, the President of the United States just said "I don't think, given past performance, that we can count" on Russia to uphold their end of the bargain.

31  USA: Alfa Romeo will start selling cars in the United States again this year, after leaving the market in mid-90s. Before you get all excited, here's the sad quote: "The company says it expects to sell just under a thousand regular 4C models, at a base price of $54,000, by the end of this year."

32  USA: An unnamed man urinated in a water reservoir that serves the city of Portland, Oregon. What does Portland decide to do with said reservoir? Empty it. All 38 million gallons (143 million liters).

33  USA: Barack Obama has announced "more than eight million Americans have enrolled for health coverage, with 35% of those under age 35."

34  USA: Keith Seilhan, age 47, will have to pay a $224,118 fine for insider trading. He sold $1 million of BP shares after finding out just how bad the Gulf of Mexico oil spill was. Note that he was in charge of the "initial cleanup operations."

35  USA: Michaels, the arts and crafts store chain, says 2.6 million credit card numbers may have been stolen. This obviously isn't Target scale damage, but it's still a disturbing trend.

36  USA: North Dakota's ban on abortion has been overturned.

37  USA: Walmart is launching a competitor to Western Union called "Walmart-2-Walmart". It'll only work in the United States. I have just one question: Do people not know that the U.S. Postal Service offers extremely cheap money orders?

38  World: 420 is universally understood to be slang for marijuana. What's the origin story of that number? In 1971, a bunch of guys from Northern California would always smoke weed together after school at roughly 04:20 PM every day. They started to use that term amongst themselves, and the rest is history.

39  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

40  One more thing: Tradition dictates I remind you Tab Dump via email exists on Friday.

item.title: April 17: 44 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  This spot is reserved for sponsors. If you want more details, send me an email.

02  Podcast: The latest episode of The Voicemail, which James Whatley and I record every week, is live. We covered the iPhone 6 leak, the LG G3 leak, the Galaxy S5's fingerprint scanner, and answered several listener questions.

03  Apple: Bloomberg says Apple will partner with Shazam in order to add song identification to iOS 8. It should be noted that the ability to identify the song you're listening to is already baked into Android and Windows Phone.

04  Apple: They launched the 8 GB iPhone 5c in 16 new European countries.

05  Apps: Frontback, an app that combines a photo from both your rear and front facing cameras in one image, is finally available on Android. Sadly, the insane hype it generated when it came out for iOS over half a year ago has all but disappeared. Note that less than 10,000 people have installed it.

06  AT&T: The FCC wants to auction off some spectrum next year, but they don't want the big wireless operators to buy it all up. This has AT&T so pissed off that they're threatening to not participate in the auction at all. The exact rules of the auction aren't set in stone, however, and they're expected to be finalized on May 15th.

07  Google: Accessing your computer with VNC or Microsoft Remote Desktop isn't new, but Google is now offering a free first party solution called "Chrome Remote Desktop". Just install a Chrome extension on your Mac or PC, install an app on your Android device, and you're done.

08  Google: iFixit has torn apart Project Tango, Google's prototype smartphone that doubles as a pocket 3D scanner. They found a chip in the device from PrimeSense, a company that Apple purchased last year.

09  Google: Images have leaked of a completely redesigned Google+ app for Android. The design matches the recently leaked Gmail and Calendar apps. Expect design to be a major focus of Google I/O, which kicks off on June 25th.

10  Google: The Calendar app in Android now uses the Google Maps backend to let you enter the locations of your meetings using plain English. Example: Whole Foods on Ocean Avenue.

11  Google: The Head of Europe's largest newspaper publisher, Mathias Döpfner, says Google's business model is a "protection racket" and that their motto should be "if you don't want us to finish you off, you better pay."

12  Google: The technology they've developed to read the numbers on buildings that are photographed with a Google Street View car can apparently decode CAPTCHAs with an accuracy rate of 99%. So why are websites still using CAPTCHAs then?

13  Google: Their Q1 2014 financial results are out. Here are the two numbers people are focusing on: "Google's recorded cost-per-click average rate fell 9%. Total paid clicks rose 26% year-over-year."

14  Google: They've ripped the camera app out of Android and are now providing it as a download via the Play Store to any device running Android 4.4 KitKat or higher. Best feature? It won't allow you to record videos in portrait mode.

15  Google: Think Google I/O is an event just for developers? The company has announced a series of "sessions and workshops focused on design and designers." Make sure to watch the Jony Ive inspired videos.

16  Heartbleed: Stephen Arthuro Solis-Reyes, 19 years old, has officially become the first person to be arrested for maliciously using the Heartbleed bug. He's accused of hacking into Canada's version of the IRS and stealing over 900 social security numbers.

17  IBM: "IBM reported its lowest quarterly revenue in five years on Wednesday as the company struggles with falling demand for its storage and server products."

18  Japan: For reasons I don't understand, a Japanese researcher has invented a pair of glasses with two screens that face outward instead of inward. Said glasses "could be used to simulate emotional reactions", but why?

19  LG: The Verge has obtained a photo of the retail box that LG's next flagship phone, the LG G3, will ship in. LG also confirmed to The Verge that "its next phone will feature a 2560 x 1440 screen resolution."

20  LG: They're going to start making their own chips "soon", possibly this quarter. And by "make", I mean design. TSMC will be responsible for the actual manufacturing. Going vertical is what all the cool kids seem to be doing these days.

21  Microsoft: They're slashing the price of Windows XP support so that they don't appear to be too greedy. One example given was an unnamed client with 10,000 computers running XP. Microsoft originally wanted $2 million to continue support, but they dropped that down to $250,000.

22  Microsoft: They've changed the Bing homepage. It now has what can best be described as a ticker showing "cards" similar to those Google uses in Google Now.

23  Nokia: They have a factory in India that's delaying the Microsoft acquisition, leading local media to predict that the plant will stay with Nokia and not be transferred to Microsoft. What's the issue here? Nokia and the Indian government are embroiled in a tax dispute.

24  Samsung: Amazon will make a custom Kindle app for Samsung phones. Owners of the Galaxy S5 will be able to download 12 Kindle books a year for free. No, you can't have any book, Amazon will give you a choice of four books every month.

25  Samsung: Phones 4u, a fairly large independent UK mobile phone retailer, has published a press release saying that sales of the Galaxy S5 on launch day were double that of Galaxy S4 sales on its respective launch day.

26  Samsung: They've confirmed to The Verge that they're going to make an Android Wear powered smartwatch and launch it this year. Note that all of Samsung's smartwatches thus far only work with Samsung phones. Will an Android Wear powered Samsung watch work with any Android device?

27  Sony: PlayStation 4 sales have officially hit seven million units.

28  Spotify: Without peer-to-peer technology, Spotify couldn't have launched back in 2008 with their limited resources. But now that they're all grown-up, they've announced that they're going to switch from P2P to dedicated servers by the end of this year.

29  Tencent: China's biggest internet company is partnering with King to bring Candy Crush to China this summer. No financial details were mentioned. Tencent will promote the app on WeChat, which has 355 million monthly users.

30  Time Warner Cable: This American television and internet service provider has rolled out Hotspot 2.0 technology across their 33,000 WiFi access points. Translation: Connect to TWC's WiFi network once, and you'll never have to fiddle with settings or a login screen again. Expect to hear more ISPs talking about Hotspot 2.0 in the future.

31  Twitter: The UK television company Sky is allowing their subscribers to "start watching or remotely record a TV show" simply by clicking a tweet. This capability is apparently already live in the United States with Comcast, but it's the first I've heard of it.

32  Yahoo!: Re/code says Marissa Mayer is in the process of building a mobile search engine, and that her end goal is to convince Apple to set that search engine as the default in Safari on the iPhone and iPad.

The Real World

33  Argentina: Police have rescued a 15 year old girl that's been kept locked in a garage for nine years and fed only bread and water. No word as to what will happen to her foster parents, but I'm personally hoping for the worst.

34  Europe: The first images from Europe's new Copernicus space program have just been published. The Sentinel-1a satellite that captured said images was launched on April 3rd.

35  France: Earlier this week, I wrote about whiskey makers losing money because of China's new government policies on excessive gift giving. Now it's cognac's turn. Remy Cointreau just issued a warning, saying full year profits will plunge by a third, and they specifically called out China.

36  Malaysia: The Bluefin-21 submersible that's searching for the MH370 flight recorders has now had its first successful mission. The first two missions ran into issues, but with this third one, everything went to plan. Sadly, nothing has been found.

37  South Korea: The Atlantic has published 23 photos of the ferry disaster. These pictures are not easy on the eyes.

38  South Korea: The latest numbers from the ferry sinking: Nine people have died. Dozens have been injured. 170 have been rescued. 287 are still missing. What's terrifying is that over 325 of the passengers on that ferry were students from the same High School.

39  Space: Scientists say they may have witnessed the birth of Saturn's 63rd moon. They're naming it Peggy.

40  UK: More than 10 cars have had their tires punctured in a six month period in one town. Crazy kids, right? Security footage shows it was actually a dog that really hates cars.

41  UK: When you order lamb at a restaurant, there's a 30% chance it's actually not lamb. That's what the Foods Standards Agency found after testing 145 samples. They say they'll test 300 samples next month.

42  Ukraine: "Pro-Russian militants in eastern Ukraine have seized six Ukrainian armored vehicles, the defense ministry in Kiev says." Let's not bullshit each other, these are Russian soldiers, not armed countryside folks who like Putin.

43  USA: Playboy is going to republish the very first issue of their magazine (December 1953) and sell it for $10.

44  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: April 16: 46 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  This spot is reserved for sponsors. If you want more details, send me an email.

02  Alibaba: The WSJ has produced an amazing four minute video explaining what Alibaba is and why they want to raise $15 billion from their IPO. Spoiler: Alibaba's transaction volume is "more than double the size of Amazon, triple the size of eBay, and one-third larger than the value of all the transactions last year at the two U.S.-based e-commerce giants combined."

03  Amazon: The first images of Amazon's smartphone have leaked. Note that the device is in an incredibly thick case that makes it impossible to see anything meaningful. Earlier this week, the WSJ said Amazon would unveil the phone in June and ship it in September.

04  Apple: A photo of what's alleged to be the front of the iPhone 6 has leaked. Luckily, someone held an iPhone 5/5s next to said component for scale. Using some quick math, it looks like the iPhone 6 will have a 5.1 inch display. In other words, forget about the 4.7 inch and 5.5 inch iPhone rumor, there can only be one Highlander.

05  Apple: At the Hong Kong Electronics Fair, a metal brick that allegedly looks like the next iPhone is being shown off. Said brick was made so case makers have a mold to use to create their products.

06  Apple: CarPlay support will come to Pioneer's NEX series of aftermarket consoles (ranges from $700 to $1,500) via a firmware update this summer.

07  Apps: App Annie has released a slew of data points, here are my favorite three: Google Play downloads in Q1 2014 were 45% higher than iOS App Store downloads, yet iOS App Store revenues were 85% higher than Google Play Store revenues. Chinese iOS App Store revenues grew 70% sequentially (Q1 2014 versus Q4 2013).

08  Apps: BBC iPlayer for Android now allows you to download content for offline use. This functionality was previously limited to a handful of phones. Now it works on nearly every Android device out there.

09  Automattic: The company that makes WordPress is allegedly looking to raise $100 million to $150 million. There's also a pretty eye opening data point: "WordPress now powers 22% of the world's websites, up from 19% last July."

10  Bitcoin: Mark Karpeles, the guy in charge of MtGox, is supposed to attend a hearing in Washington D.C. this Friday, but he refuses to to travel to the United States.

11  Bitcoin: MtGox "has asked a Tokyo court to allow it to be liquidated." Translation: It's dead.

12  BitTorrent: The second episode of the fourth season of "Game of Thrones" set a couple of BitTorrent records: "More than 193,000 people shared a single copy yesterday evening, and roughly 1.5 million people downloaded the episode during the first day."

13  BlackBerry: They've spent an undisclosed amount of money to buy a stake in a digital health start-up called NantHealth. Said start-up offers services to 250 hospitals and connects to 16,000 medical devices.

14  DigiTimes: "Apple had a dominant market share of 58.7% for 4G smartphones sold in the China market in January-February 2014, followed by Samsung Electronics with 26.4%, Coolpad 9.4%, K-Touch 2.5%, Sony 1.2% and Huawei 0.8%, according to Sino Market Research."

15  Google: In yet another demonstration of why it's good to be vertically integrated, Gmail now allows you to attach pictures that your Android phone has automatically uploaded to Google Photos in the background with just one click.

16  Google: Matias Duarte, the Head of Android Design, sat down with the Editor in Chief of The Verge for 38 minutes. I haven't watched the video yet, so I can't say whether or not it's worth your time. Update: Watched the interview over lunch. Highly recommended.

17  Google: The latest Google Glass update enables Bluetooth Low Energy support.

18  Google: The Verge produced a delightful six minute video about Project Ara, Google's attempt to make a modular phone. I still don't know why anyone would want this, but hopefully Google will find some way to pitch the idea when it goes on sale early next year.

19  Google: The WSJ says Google is looking for "enough space to hold more than 3,000 employees" in New York City. That translates to an 80% increase in the number of NYC Google employees.

20  Intel: They published their Q1 2014 financial earnings yesterday. Key data points: $12.8 billion in revenue, $1.9 billion in earnings, the new group labeled "Mobile and Communications" only made $156 million, and "we shipped 5 million tablet processors, making strong progress on our goal of 40 million tablets for 2014."

21  LG: This is an image of a leaked LG Android phone heading to Japan. I'm putting it on Tab Dump because it has practically zero bezels, which is a design trend I think we'll soon start seeing here in the West.

22  Micromax: They've issued a denial about the rumor saying they want to buy a stake in Pantech.

23  Microsoft: Office 365 Personal is now available. Instead of paying $100 a year or $10 a month to run Office on five computers and five tablets, you can now pay $70 a year or $7 a month and have Office work on one computer and one tablet.

24  Motorola: The Head of Motorola Mobility UK is resigning. Fun Fact: He found out about the sale to Lenovo just 30 minutes before the press release hit the wires.

25  Oculus: They gave TechCrunch some sales numbers for the Oculus Rift: 25,000 second generation units. 60,000 first generation units. Total: 85,000 units.

26  Samsung: According to "Samsung insiders", the company has a goal of shipping 35 million GS5 units in Q2 2014. The insiders also say 63 million GS4 units were shipped, but only 40 million were actually sold.

27  Samsung: The company has unveiled the 210 mAh curved battery that's inside their new Gear Fit wearable device.

28  Samsung: The Galaxy S5's fingerprint scanner can be "hacked" with a piece of tape.

29  Squarespace: The service that powers this website just raised $40 million.

30  Twitter: "Twitter will close some accounts in Turkey but will not set up an office there as the government wants, a senior Turkish official said late on Monday."

31  Twitter: Daniel Graf is Twitter's new Vice President of Consumer Product. Before Twitter, he worked at Google, where he was not only in charge of Google Maps, but was also in charge of the team that wrote Google Maps for iOS.

32  Twitter: Gnip has been using their access to Twitter's firehose to sell social data to companies for years. Twitter decided they would rather sell that data to companies directly, so they just bought Gnip. Price unknown.

33  USA: Five of America's biggest wireless operators, and pretty much every handset maker that sells devices in the U.S., have voluntarily agreed to ship phones with "kill-switches" built-in starting July 2015. For what it's worth, both Android and iOS have this feature out of the box, but most people don't configure it.

34  Yahoo!: They published their Q1 2014 financial earnings. Key data points: $312 million in profits, 8% increase in employees (12,400 total), 430 million monthly mobile users.

The Real World

35  India: The Supreme Court has ruled that "transgender" is the third official sex. There are an estimated two million people in the country who identify as being transgender.

36  Iraq: The infamous Abu Ghraib prison has been shut down. Its 2,400 inmates have been relocated to other nearby facilities.

37  Malaysia: The data captured by the Bluefin-21 submersible has been analyzed. Nothing was found. It's been deployed again, but the U.S. Navy says it could take "from six weeks to two months to scan the search zone."

38  Russia: Because of the situation in Ukraine, Russia's Finance Minister, Anton Siluanov, says the country will have 0% growth this year, and that it's facing "the most difficult conditions since the 2008 crisis."

39  South Korea: A ferry carrying over 470 people has just sunk. One person has died. 179 people have been rescued. This is an ongoing operation.

40  UK: A barber shop that used a photo of Kim Jong-un in an advertisement was visited by two men from the North Korean Embassy. They demanded to speak to the manager. The manager proceeded to throw them out.

41  UK: Remember that Polish politician I wrote about that wanted to go to the UK and live off £100 a week to see why people from his country are leaving in droves? He's been there since April 5th, he quickly realized his budget was far too small, and he's now working as a handyman. He plans on returning on the 22nd.

42  UK: The Trussell Trust says they handed out 347,000 boxes of food to those less fortunate in 2012. In 2013, that number skyrocketed to 913,000 boxes. Why the rise? The new welfare system.

43  Ukraine: Vladimir Putin called up Angela Merkel and told her that Ukraine is "on the verge of civil war".

44  USA: "The New York Police Department has disbanded a secret program designed to eavesdrop on Muslims to identify potential terrorism threats." The program has been in operation since 2003.

45  World: There's a new field of science out there called "neurogastronomy". Chefs, food companies, whiskey makers, they're all discovering something that we've all instinctively known for years: The environment in which you consume something is often as important as the food or drink you're consuming. Even simple things, like the color and shape of a plate, changes how people perceive their meal.

46  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: April 15: 36 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  This spot is reserved for sponsors. If you want more details, send me an email.

02  Apple: According to Jefferies analyst Peter Misek, rumor has it that Apple is trying to get U.S. wireless operators to price the upcoming iPhone 6 at $299 with a two year contract instead of $199 with a two year contract. As someone who buys only unlocked smartphones, this has me wondering if the base model iPhone 6 will cost over 800 Euros.

03  Apple: Another photo of an alleged Foxconn mold for the upcoming iPhone 6 has surfaced.

04  Apple: Rumor has it that LG will be the sole display maker for the upcoming iWatch, it'll launch in September, and Apple is expecting to sell nine million units in calendar 2014.

05  Apple: Want to use CarPlay, but don't want to buy a new car? Rumor has it Alpine will start selling an aftermarket console in the U.S. and Europe this fall for between $500 and $700.

06  DigiTimes: Intel is allegedly selling their CPUs for tablets for less than $5 in China in order to better compete with MediaTek and Allwinner.

07  eBay: Data Point: "Last year 73% of the items on its website were sold at a fixed price, rather than via auction."

08  Facebook: According to an article from The Financial Times that's behind a paywall, Facebook is "only weeks away" from launching a PayPal-like service in Europe.

09  Google: "Google updated its terms of service on Monday, informing users that their incoming and outgoing emails are automatically analyzed by software to create targeted ads." In other news, water is wet.

10  Google: Android 4.4.3 (the newest version of the OS) is being pushed out to Nexus 5 owners using the Sprint network. The changelog has just two line items: "Enable Sprint Spark band 26 and band 41. Misc Android updates." No word as to when other devices will get this update, but I'm assuming it'll be sooner rather than later, and hopefully we'll also get a more detailed list of the updates within.

11  Google: Chrome OS has been updated. It now supports a feature Microsoft introduced in Windows 8, the ability to dock (Microsoft says "snap") small apps to the side of your screen.

12  Google: Facebook wanted to buy Titan Aerospace, but Google just beat them to the punch. No price was mentioned. Titan builds solar powered drones, has roughly 20 employees, and is based out of New Mexico.

13  Google: They've announced a "subtle, but big" software update for Google Glass that will be pushed out later this week. From what I can tell, it's mainly just bug fixes and battery life improvements. Video calling has been removed because the experience was less than ideal.

14  Heartbleed: Canada's version of the IRS says that because of Heartbleed, 900 social security numbers were stolen.

15  HTC: If you own an "old" HTC One, and want the software that ships on the 2014 HTC One, you'll be happy to know you're due to get an update by the end of May.

16  Journalism: Here's the list of publications and journalists that won a Pulitzer this year.

17  LG: ZDNET Korea is reporting that LG's next flagship phone, the G3, will be released in July and feature a 5.5 inch screen with a resolution of 2560 x 1440 pixels. We're talking 534 pixels per inch here.

18  Microsoft: If you have a Windows Phone, and you want to test Windows Phone 8.1 right now instead of waiting for your device maker or operator to push out an update, here's everything you need to know.

19  Microsoft: Office Online is now available via the Chrome Web Store. It's free, but note that you don't get all the features of Office. Think of this more like Microsoft's version of Google Docs.

20  Microsoft: Windows Phone 8.1 appears to somehow be compatible with Apple's Passbook, but no one is entirely sure if this is officially sanctioned.

21  Netflix: They've published a chart ranking the best performing ISPs in the U.S. for the month of March. That's not very interesting. What's interesting is that Comcast's average streaming speeds jumped 65% after they struck a deal with Netflix.

22  Open Source: Apple has Siri. Google has Google Now. Microsoft has Cortana. But what about the open source community? Meet Jasper.

23  Security: Remember all those credit cards that were stolen from Target? No one wants that to happen again, ever, so the "National Retail Federation said on Monday it will establish an Information Sharing and Analysis Center, or ISAC, for the retail industry in June."

24  Square: The woman responsible for Amazon's infrastructure, Alyssa Henry, is now in charge of Square's infrastructure.

25  USA: Drone technology is advancing so rapidly that the Pentagon has a stockpile of old units just collecting dust. They've decided to put them to good use by transforming them into Wi-Fi hotspots for soldiers in the field.

The Real World

26  Asia: Researchers have found a link between increased pollution and stronger storms. Tiny pollutant particles make storm clouds denser, which in turn causes increased precipitation.

27  Australia: The city of Sydney is going to get a second international airport. They've been wanting one since as far back as 1946. It's going to cost $2.4 billion to build, it'll be done in the mid-2020s, and it's expected to bring with it 60,000 jobs.

28  China: Crazy Number of the Day: The Chinese bought 1,132 tons of gold in 2013. Your typical Honda Civic weighs less than 1.5 tons.

29  France: An auction for roughly 40 pieces of Nazi memorabilia, including Goering's passport and a napkin used by Hitler, was canceled due to complaints that assigning value to these objects is disgusting.

30  Malaysia: The robotic submarine searching for the MH370 flight recorder had to cut its mission short because its built-in safety system wouldn't allow it to dive any deeper. Note that the sub is rated to withstand depths of 4,500 meters (15,000 feet).

31  Mongolia: This brief, but beautiful photo essay shows how one young girl uses a golden eagle to hunt for food. Make sure you scroll to the bottom.

32  Netherlands: Street lights are expensive. Glow in the dark paint is not. That's the logic the Dutch are using to test a 500 meter stretch of highway to see how well people can get by with just the green paint.

33  Space: SpaceX had to abort the launch of a Falcon-9 rocket yesterday because one of its sensors detected a helium leak. Said rocket was supposed to carry two tons of food and supplies to the space station.

34  Ukraine: Barack Obama called Vladimir Putin and told him to stop whatever it is he's doing in East Ukraine, and that even if he wasn't responsible, he should use his power to get pro-Russian forces in the region to stop acting like a bunch of madmen.

35  USA: "U.S. retail sales saw their biggest gain in 18 months in March, according to official figures. Sales at general merchandise stores such as Wal-Mart, Target and department stores, rose by 1.9%, their strongest one-month gain since March 2007."

36  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: April 14: 38 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  This spot is reserved for sponsors. If you want more details, send me an email.

02  Amazon: The WSJ says Amazon will announce a phone in June and then start selling it in September. The key selling point will be four front facing cameras that enable the device to "make some images appear to be 3-D, similar to a hologram."

03  Apple: These are allegedly the molds Foxconn will be using to make the 4.7 inch iPhone 6.

04  Apple: They banned a UK online streaming radio company from advertising on iAd because they're "a competitive service to iTunes Radio and it is against Apple policy".

05  DigiTimes: You know how HTC's 2014 flagship phone, the M8, has two rear facing cameras? Altek, one of the companies that makes dual-camera modules for smartphones, says Lenovo and Huawei will follow in HTC's footsteps this quarter. Samsung and Apple will do the same in 2015.

06  Dropbox: For those of you that like to watch press conferences, here's the one Dropbox held on the 9th.

07  Dropbox: Here's the (borderline useless) three paragraph response Dropbox has issued to those concerned about Condoleezza Rice joining the Dropbox board.

08  Facebook: In 2010, Facebook had seven people on a hardware team dedicated to servers. Today, that number is 170. They spent $1.36 billion on data centers last year.

09  Google: "Google's federal lobbying spending now ranks on par with the largest U.S. corporations active in Washington. The company went from 213th place in 2004 to second in 2012." So how much did Google actually spend on lobbying in 2012 in order to reach silver status? $18.2 million.

10  Google: According to Android Police, which is killing it in the Google rumor department, these are the new icons that Google will use for the next version of Android. They represent a much flatter design language, some might say even iOS 7-ish. Expect to hear more about the next version of Android at I/O on June 25th.

11  Google: I'm keeping one eye on the Apple/Samsung trial in case any interesting data points come out. Hiroshi Lockheimer, Google VP of Engineering for Android, recently testified that the Android team is made up of 600 to 700 people. In 2006, it was 20 to 30 people.

12  Heartbleed: "The U.S. National Security Agency has denied it knew about or exploited the Heartbleed online security flaw. The denial came after a Bloomberg News report alleging the NSA used the flaw in OpenSSL to harvest data."

13  Intellectual Ventures: One of the world's best known patent trolls is looking to raise $3 billion. Microsoft and Sony said sure, we'll give you some money. Apple and Intel said no, go away, despite the fact that they've both contributed in the past.

14  Micromax: Indian phone maker Micromax wants to buy a stake in Korean phone maker Pantech. No word as to how big of a stake.

15  Microsoft: Remember Project Tango, Google's prototype phone that has a built-in 3D scanner? Microsoft just announced their own version of it, and it's called Skynet of all things.

16  Microsoft: They're now allowing apps in the Windows Store (the app store for the desktop) to be priced at either $0.99 or $1.29. The company says 55% of all apps purchased on Windows Phone fall into those two categories.

17  O2 UK: This operator recently hit one million 4G LTE customers. In their announcement was this eye-popping data point: "Customers used more data in the 4G network's first six months than the entire O2 network carried between 2000 and 2008."

18  Oculus: Sir David Attenborough is filming a new nature documentary called "Conquest of the Skies" that's specifically meant to be viewed on the Oculus Rift.

19  Qualcomm: They're asking the FCC to open up spectrum in the 10 GHz band. The only reason I even mention this story is because I never knew companies were even looking into this absurdly high frequency band.

20  Samsung: A lot of people are pointing to this article on ZDNET Korea, which says Galaxy S5 opening day sales are between 130% to 200% better than Galaxy S4 sales, but the exact source of those two numbers isn't mentioned, so do exercise caution.

21  Samsung: They're going to unveil a camera focused smartphone on the 29th.

22  Twitter: "A report from Twopcharts, a website that monitors Twitter account activity, states that about 44% of the 974 million existing Twitter accounts have never sent a tweet." Plenty of people are talking about this report, and they're saying it doesn't matter if people don't tweet, because one doesn't need to tweet to enjoy the benefits of Twitter. But what does Twitter want?

The Real World

23  China: They just dropped $6 billion on a copper mine in Peru. Said mine is expected to supply 450,000 tons of copper a year for the first five years it's open.

24  Finland: This September, "Tom of Finland" stamps will go on sale in Finland. If you don't know who "Tom of Finland" is, he's famous for drawing homosexual men in various ... poses.

25  Germany: "The U.S. government is refusing to grant Angela Merkel access to her NSA file or answer formal questions from Germany about its surveillance activities." Reminder: Merkel grew up in East Germany, so this stuff is all too familiar to her.

26  Germany: A furniture store chain ordered 5,000 coffee cups from China. Said cups featured a portrait of Hitler. The store chain sold about 175 of the cups until someone pointed Hitler out. The remaining cups have been destroyed.

27  Malaysia: "Teams searching for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane are to deploy a submersible for the first time." It's called the Bluefin-21, and it'll be sent to the area where four pings from the flight boxes were heard.

28  Norway: Remember that beautiful Breivik massacre memorial that was planned? The families of the victims don't want it to be built. They're "getting sick" of being constantly reminded about the tragedy, and will take the government to court if construction of the memorial begins.

29  Scotland: Xi Jinping became China's new president in March 2013. He promised to tackle corruption and excessive "gift giving". Result? Sales of whiskey to China dropped 30% in 2013 according to the Scotch Whisky Association (SWA).

30  South Korea: "South Korea's state health insurer is suing three tobacco firms to offset smoking-related treatment costs." How much do they want? $52 million, which seems ridiculous considering they spend $1.6 billion a year to treat "smoking-related diseases."

31  Switzerland: Take four small jet engines, attach them to a stick, and make someone strapped to a snowboard hold said stick. Rarely does one get to witness the birth of a new extreme sport.

32  Ukraine: The deadline that the Ukrainian government gave to Pro-Russian militants to end their occupation of certain government buildings in the Eastern part of the country has passed. The militants haven't budged an inch.

33  USA: "A new treatment for hepatitis C 'cured' 90% of patients with the infection in 12 weeks, scientists said." The drug was tested on 380 patients last year. Two trials took place, one of which lasted 12 weeks, the other double that.

34  USA: Man hurls racist insults and spits on neighbors, including their disabled kids in wheelchairs. Judge orders him to stand outside with a sign that says "I am a bully", plus 15 days of jail time.

35  USA: Researchers have invented a pair of augmented reality goggles that allow surgeons to "see" cancer. A patient is injected with a special dye that sticks to cancer cells, and said dye gives off "light" at a wavelength only the glasses can see.

36  Venezuela: The death toll from the protests has hit 41.

37  World: Here's a list of 10 inventions that wouldn't have been possible without the first World War. Some of the items, such as the vegetarian sausage and daylight savings time, are quite surprising.

38  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: April 11: 42 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: Igloo, makers of an intranet you'll actually like, are happy to announce an OEM partnership with Swisscom. Under the trademark Dynamic Intranet, Swisscom will host and distribute Igloo's cloud intranet solution to their customers in Switzerland, Germany, and Italy. This offers Swisscom's European customers a state-of-the-art hosting facility in Zürich, while Igloo's North American and international customers continue to be hosted at CenturyLink facilities in Canada.

02  Advertising: "Digital ad revenues surpassed broadcast television for the first time." We're talking $42.8 billion spent in 2013 on internet advertising versus $40.1 billion on TV. There are a ton of data points in this article, so enjoy.

03  Amazon: Their app store now has 200,000 apps. "The Amazon Appstore launched in March 2011 with 3,800 apps. Amazon reported having 100,000 apps in August 2013."

04  Amazon: They spent an undisclosed amount of money to buy comiXology, which can best be thought of as Kindle-like service for comic books.

05  BlackBerry: Yesterday, Reuters quoted the CEO of BlackBerry as saying "If I cannot make money on handsets, I will not be in the handset business." That quote went viral, so the CEO decided to issue a correction on the company blog. And I quote: "We have not given up and we are not leaving the devices business."

06  ChangeWave: A lot of people are quoting a new survey published by ChangeWave that says 14% of people (sample size 4,109) want to buy an iPhone 6 because it has a larger screen. Personally, I think surveys that ask people what they want to buy mean little to nothing, and that the only data worth analyzing is sales data. That being said, of course people want a bigger iPhone!

07  Deezer: This Spotify clone just announced that people will be able to "listen to smart radios for free" on their mobile phone, but the bigger news is this: "The company also announced a new partnership with Samsung in Europe. New Samsung Galaxy S5 owners will get 6 months of Premium+." That's $85 worth of unlimited music streaming.

08  DigiTimes: "Microsoft will set up four additional Azure data centers in 2014 and is expected to expand its procurement orders to server ODMs." So instead of calling up Dell and HP and ordering servers, Microsoft is going straight to the companies that build the servers in the first place.

09  Dropbox: Buried in all of yesterday's Dropbox news was this little nugget: Condoleezza Rice is joining the Dropbox board. This is the same woman that authorized warrantless wiretapping and who is best buddies with the NSA. This should be more controversial than some guy donating $1,000 to ban gay marriage, but no one seems to care.

10  eBay: "Activist investor Carl Icahn has dropped his call for eBay to sell its payments business, PayPal." He still thinks eBay should spin-off PayPal, but he's acknowledged it's not going to happen with the current board.

11  Facebook: Researchers using a sample set of 881 female U.S. college students have discovered "the more time women spent on Facebook, the more they compared their bodies with those of their friends, and the more they felt negative about their appearance."

12  Facebook: The United States Federal Trade Commission just approved the WhatsApp purchase, but with one string attached. Facebook can't use WhatsApp's data without getting explicit permission from WhatsApp's users.

13  Google: "According to Google, video views of TV-related content on YouTube grew 35% in 2013 from the previous year, while time spent viewing TV-related content on the site jumped 65% over that period. Furthermore, Google searches for TV content were up 16% year over year." The report with all these figures is here.

14  Google: On April 15th, starting at 06:00 California time, anyone in the U.S. will be able to plop down $1,500 for a pair of Google Glass. This is a one day only sale.

15  Google: They just announced an always-on antivirus service for Android, but specifically didn't use the word "antivirus", because that just has too many negative connotations.

16  Heartbleed: "U.S. financial regulators on Thursday told banks to upgrade their systems as soon as possible." That kind of goes without saying, right?

17  HTC: A Singaporean operator is reporting that several of the HTC One M8 units they've sold are having SIM card issues. Reminder: This is the company's brand new flagship phone.

18  LINE: My favorite chat app says they plan on hitting "500 million to 600 million users by the end of this year" and over one billion users at some point in 2015. They're growing at a rate of roughly 1.7 million users a day.

19  Microsoft: Their cloud service is now the first and only cloud service that's compatible with the European Union's privacy laws.

20  Samsung: "Samsung expects S5 sales to reach 10 million units within 25 days based on pre-orders from global wireless operators, Seoul Economic Daily reported today, citing an unidentified Samsung official."

21  Square: According to Re/code, both Google and Apple are interested in buying Square, with the rumored acquisition price being roughly $8 billion. Square might decide to do their own thing, however, and IPO. What I want to know is what's Square going to do come October 2015 when chip and pin cards become mandatory in the U.S.?

22  Staples: "Staples has been selling 3D printers for about a year. Now it wants to begin selling access to them. The office supply retailer began offering 3D printing services in two stores on Thursday, one in New York and another in Los Angeles." Prices range, depending on what you're printing, from several dollars to thousands.

23  Television: Everyone fiddles with their phone while watching TV, right? According to a survey on 1,665 Americans between the ages of 15 to 54, the answer is no. "Only 16.1% of the survey respondents said they had used social media while watching TV during prime time. And less than half of the people using social media were actually discussing the show they were watching."

24  Turkey: As predicted, YouTube is still banned, despite what the courts have said.

25  Twitter: If you use Twitter via Twitter's desktop website, you can now look forward to notifications, just like Facebook.

The Real World

26  Brazil: This is the world's most insane football (read: soccer) fan. Two minute video.

27  Europe: Ukraine has some unpaid gas bills ($2.2 billion). Russia, which supplies about a third of the EU's natural gas, is now threatening 18 European countries with gas cuts if it doesn't get paid. The U.S. is of course waving their finger at Russia, but not much else.

28  Health: One BBC reporter tried to go one week without eating processed foods. She documented her diet. I'm stunned she had so much difficulty eating healthy, because I'm pretty sure fruits and vegetables are quite easy to find in Western countries.

29  Japan: Despite Fukushima, the Japanese government just announced that they're going to reactivate some of the country's nuclear power plants.

30  Malaysia: Four pings thought to originate from the MH370 black boxes have been detected. A fifth ping was recently heard, but it's now been debunked by the Australian Joint Acoustic Analysis Center.

31  Nigeria: A 14 year old girl was forced to marry a 35 year old man. She didn't want any part of it, so she poisoned the food at the wedding. Not only did the husband die, but so did three other people; 10 people were sent to the hospital.

32  Russia: "Five members of Russia's parliament have called for the former president, Mikhail Gorbachev, to be prosecuted over the collapse of the Soviet Union." 1991 called. They want their headline back.

33  Somalia: What happens when the residents of Mogadishu access the internet via a fiber optic connection for the first time? They report "culture shock" and joy for finally having the ability to use YouTube.

34  Syria: Only 54% of the country's reported 1,200 tons of chemical weapons has been sent to factories to be destroyed. The country agreed to send all their chemical weapons by the 27th of this month.

35  UK: "In a study of 847 men with prostate cancer, 209 out of the 415 who were initially told their cancer was slow-growing were found to have a more aggressive form of the disease. And for almost a third of the 415 men, it had spread around the body." Translation: Today's cancer tests are terrible. As someone who lost a parent to cancer, this upsets me.

36  UK: Man sexually abuses 13 year old girl. Man goes to jail. Man asks police to give his laptop back, which has images of said abused girl. Technically, the police have to fulfill his request. Outrage ensues.

37  USA: "A woman has thrown a shoe at former First Lady Hillary Clinton as she was giving a speech in Las Vegas." This is a 53 second video, not an article.

38  USA: "Health Secretary Kathleen Sebelius is resigning following the problematic launch of President Barack Obama's healthcare law." She's been at her post since 2009. Rumor has it Obama will replace her with Sylvia Mathews Burwell, Director of the White House Office of Management and Budget.

39  USA: Researchers studying how flies move have discovered that they use the same type of aerial techniques that fighter jet pilots use, namely split-second banking (aka rolling). It takes as little as five milliseconds for a fly to change the direction it's heading.

40  USA: Walmart is getting into the organic food business. They promise that their organic food prices will be at least 25% cheaper than competing organic food brands.

41  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

42  One more thing: Tradition dictates I remind you Tab Dump via email exists on Friday.

item.title: April 10: 49 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: Igloo, makers of an intranet you'll actually like, are happy to announce an OEM partnership with Swisscom. Under the trademark Dynamic Intranet, Swisscom will host and distribute Igloo's cloud intranet solution to their customers in Switzerland, Germany, and Italy. This offers Swisscom's European customers a state-of-the-art hosting facility in Zürich, while Igloo's North American and international customers continue to be hosted at CenturyLink facilities in Canada.

02  Alibaba: Think of Alibaba as a sort of eBay and Amazon mixed together, but with higher revenues. They just bought a 20% stake in a Chinese online TV company for $1 billion. Note that Alibaba is expected to IPO soon, and they're going to be worth more than Facebook.

03  Apple: "Apple is set to add four digital agencies to its roster, including WPP's AKQA and Interpublic Group's Huge on the West Coast, as well as small, New York-based indie shops Area 17 and Kettle, Ad Age has learned."

04  Apple: "iTunes Radio, which launched in September with much fanfare, so far only sees about 1% to 2% of listeners clicking the buy button." Not only that, but Apple now makes up 50% of the record labels' revenues, whereas it used to be 70% in 2012. According to Billboard, this situation is "forcing" Apple to speed up plans to offer a Spotify-like subscription music streaming service.

05  Apple: Human Interface Chief Greg Christie is leaving Apple. Some say it's because he didn't get along with Jony Ive. Others say he's just ready to retire after being with Apple for 18 years. One thing is certain: We'll never know the real reason.

06  Apple: KGI Research analyst Ming-Chi Kuo, who has a pretty good track record when it comes to Apple rumors, says that in Q3 2014 we're going to see a new iPad Air, a new iPad mini, two iWatches (different sizes), a 4.7 inch iPhone 6, a new Apple TV, and a new 12.0 inch MacBook. There will be a larger 5.5 inch iPhone 6 in Q4. As for the 12.9 inch "iPad Pro", that's a 2015 product. Should you believe Kuo's predictions? My brain says maybe, but my gut says no.

07  Apple: There was a DigiTimes rumor yesterday that said Apple wanted to make their own baseband chips, aka the part of the phone that talks to the cellular network. Today, AppleInsider has discovered two very senior Broadcom engineers have left to join Apple. In total, 30 RF engineers from Broadcom and Qualcomm have joined Apple over the past three years, and there are 50+ job openings on Apple's website relating to RF. Translation: The company that's known for being vertically integrated is taking things to the next level.

08  AUO: This display maker has unveiled a 5.7 inch 2560 x 1440 pixel AMOLED panel. No word as to when it'll enter mass production. It should be noted that all the AMOLED panels Samsung uses are made by Samsung themselves, so I'm not even sure who would buy AUO's AMOLED panels.

09  Automattic: The makers of WordPress just bought Longreads. Financial details weren't disclosed.

10  BlackBerry: The company's CEO just straight up said: "If I cannot make money on handsets, I will not be in the handset business."

11  Coursera: This online education company is "creating an international network of 'learning hubs', where students can follow virtual courses in real-life, brick and mortar settings." Turns out that people like being around people, and not just starring at a glowing rectangle. How many of these hubs are there? More than 30, and they're "run by partner organizations", not Coursera themselves.

12  Dropbox: They released a Flickr/Instagram clone for Android and iOS called "Carousel". It's essentially a new way to view the photos you've backed up to Dropbox, plus there's a social network built on top.

13  Dropbox: They've released Mailbox for Android. Apparently it's a popular email app. Color me surprised, I've never heard of it until now.

14  Dropbox: With "Project Harmony", Dropbox is bringing what looks like Google Drive levels of chat support and collaboration to Microsoft Office. More details will be released tomorrow.

15  Facebook: "Facebook has crossed 100 million active users in India -- the second country, after the United States, in which it has done so."

16  Facebook: The ads on the right side of their website will soon get bigger, but fewer of them will be displayed. Because bigger ads equals more attention, right?

17  Facebook: They're "starting to notify users they'll no longer have the option to send and receive messages in Facebook for iOS and Android, and will instead have to download Facebook Messenger to chat on mobile." Personally, I use m.facebook.com on my phone during those rare times I want to look at Facebook while I'm out on the town. Not installing Facebook improves your phone's battery life. Try it.

18  Google: Android Police says Google Now will soon be adding a feature that will "detect when you get out of your car, and attempt to remember that location for later, serving you a card with Google's best guess as to where you left your vehicle."

19  Google: Companies looking to contribute to Project Ara, Google's attempt at creating a modular mobile phone, can now download the "Module Developers Kit" from Google's website. As for when Ara devices and modules will ship, Google says Q1 2015, but that's just a target.

20  Google: Google Ventures has bought a stake in a robotics company called Savioke. The size of said stake is not known, but the company says they've received $2 million in seed funding. Savioke wants to build robots for the service industry. Their website says "hotels, elderly care facilities, hospitals, and restaurants [are] possibilities."

21  Google: The website that previously leaked Google's newly designed Gmail app has now leaked Google's newly designed Calendar app. It's hard to judge how pretty this looks based on a few images, but hopefully we'll see this new redesigned version of Android at Google I/O on June 25th.

22  Heartbleed: The first real meaningful Heartbleed story: "Canada shut down its online tax-filing services just weeks before millions of Canadians must file their tax returns."

23  HP: "Hewlett-Packard agreed to pay $108 million to resolve wide-ranging U.S. government investigations into whether some of its foreign units bribed government officials to obtain lucrative contracts, U.S. officials said on Wednesday."

24  IDC: These analysts say 73.4 million computers were shipped in Q1 2014, which is down 4.4% year over year. Lenovo shipped the most computers, giving them 17.7% market share. HP was in second place with 17.1%. And Dell was in third with 13.4%.

25  Land Rover: What happens when you mix augmented reality with off-roading? You get a concept car with a "transparent" hood that lets you see the ground that you're driving on and the direction of your wheels.

26  Microsoft: They're partnering with Lenovo and Tencent to offer support for Windows XP, which according to data cited by the state news agency Xinhua, runs on 70% of the computers in the country.

27  Motorola: "Rick Osterloh has been named as President and COO of Motorola Mobility." Note that the sale to Lenovo still hasn't gone through, and no one really knows what Lenovo will do with Motorola's top executives.

28  Mozilla: Images of Firefox OS 2.0 have leaked. Spoiler: It's basically iOS 7.

29  Nikon: The first Android powered Nikon point and shoot didn't sell. Will the new COOLPIX S810c? Probably not. Spoiler: 3.7 inch screen, 16 megapixels, 12x optical zoom, Android 4.2.2 with all of Google's services baked in.

30  Nokia: Despite being days away from being eaten up by Microsoft, they just announced a new $55 feature phone. Naturally, Bing is preloaded.

31  Quora: The premium version of Yahoo! Answers just raised $80 million at a $900 million valuation.

32  Samsung: For those who are curious about what's inside Samsung's new smart watches, this is for you. Spoiler: The Gear 2 and Gear 2 Neo use a Samsung made dual core 1 GHz Exynos 3250 chip. The Gear Fit (long skinny screen) uses an STMicroelectronics STM32F439 chip that features a 180 MHz ARM Cortex M4.

33  Samsung: The company "has knocked around a tenth off the price of its Galaxy S5 in South Korea, in the first such move for a marquee smartphone launch." The phone technically launches tomorrow, yet it's already been discounted in Korea?

34  StoreDot: Remember that company that demoed a new type of battery technology that could fully recharge in 30 seconds? The founder was interviewed on television and revealed that the quick charge battery in question only lasts two to three hours on a charge. Translation: StoreDot scammed the internet.

35  Swrve: This app testing company, using a sample size of 10 million mobile gamers, has come up with some pretty mind blowing stats: 19% of new games downloaded are only opened once. 66% of gamers stop playing a game 24 hours after they installed it. Only 2.2% of mobile gamers spend money on games, and 10% of them are responsible for 46% of all the revenues. Translation: Making money off mobile gaming is hard.
