36  WiFi: "The WiFi Alliance has updated its WiFi Protected Setup certification program to include tap-to-connect functionality via NFC." Go to your friend's house, tap their router, you're connected. Took long enough.

The Real World

37  China: For the first time since 2009, Chinese exports have fallen for two consecutive months. Translation: Slowing economy.

38  France: "New labour laws in France now make it illegal for workers in the digital and consultancy sectors - including the French offices of Google, Facebook, Deloitte, and PwC - to respond to work emails after 6 PM."

39  Japan: "Humans are taking the place of machines in [Toyota] plants across Japan so workers can develop new skills and figure out ways to improve production lines and the car-building process." So while everyone else is adding more robots, Toyota is saying nope, let's add more humans.

40  Malaysia: The Washington Post has done the impossible. They've made an "infographic" that's actually useful. It shows just how deep the MH370 flight recorder is in the Indian Ocean. Prepare to scroll. A lot.

41  Switzerland: This three minute video is a tour of a new airplane that will attempt to fly around the world next year using nothing but 18,000 solar cells embedded in its wings.

42  UK: "Just three out of 43 police forces in England and Wales have a comprehensive plan to deal with a large-scale cyber attack, a report has found." But under what circumstances would a cyber attack become a police matter?

43  UK: Research that was previously hidden, but is now available, says Tamiflu is about as useful as ordinary paracetamol (better known as Tylenol or Panadol). This is a pain point when you consider that the the U.K. government spent $795 million on a massive Tamiflu stockpile back when swine flu was a thing.

44  USA: "An attacker armed with two knives has gone on a rampage at a high school in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania, stabbing 21 students and a security guard. A suspect, named as Alex Hribal, 16, was arrested at Franklin Regional High School in Murrysville near Pittsburgh."

45  USA: "Bank of America has agreed to pay $783 million in fines and refunds to settle accusations it misled customers about its credit card services."

46  USA: "Republicans in the U.S. Senate have blocked a Democratic bill aimed at closing the gap between what men and women are paid. The Paycheck Fairness Act fell seven votes short of the 60 required to advance in the chamber."

47  USA: "The Los Angeles Police Commission is investigating how half of the recording antennas in the Southeast Division went missing, seemingly as a way to evade new self-monitoring procedures that the Los Angeles Police Department imposed last year." The watchers don't like being watched.

48  USA: Scientists have invented a new type of anchor after studying how a razor clam buries itself in the sand. This new clam is aptly called "RoboClam", but his friends call him Murphy. Practical uses? "Lay undersea cables and potentially even destroy mines."

49  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: April 09: 34 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: Igloo, makers of an intranet you'll actually like, are happy to announce an OEM partnership with Swisscom. Under the trademark Dynamic Intranet, Swisscom will host and distribute Igloo's cloud intranet solution to their customers in Switzerland, Germany, and Italy. This offers Swisscom's European customers a state-of-the-art hosting facility in Zürich, while Igloo's North American and international customers continue to be hosted at CenturyLink facilities in Canada.

02  Amazon: They say they're now the third largest video streaming service in the U.S., but what does that really mean? Netflix is number one with 57.5% of the video streaming market for the month of March. YouTube is number two with 16.9%. And finally, Amazon is number three with 6%.

03  Apple: In 2012, Samsung spent $68 million more on marketing in the U.S. than Apple. In 2013, that number fell to $12 million. Curiously, Nokia spent 15x more on marketing in 2013 than they did in 2012. That obviously worked well for them.

04  Comcast: According to an article on The Information that's behind a paywall, Comcast, America's largest cable TV provider, is thinking about launching an MVNO. When you're at home, your mobile phone will use WiFi for calls, texts, and data. When you're outside, you'll use an actual cellular network. Which network? That wasn't mentioned.

05  DigiTimes: "Apple is rumored to unveil its wearable iWatch in the third quarter and will target 65 million units in shipments for 2014." Righhht.

06  Heartbleed: This bug in the OpenSSL project, discovered by a Google employee, is getting a lot of attention. You've probably heard of it by now. Truth be told, there's a very high probability you're not going to be affected by it, yet the media continues to treat this situation like it's the end of times. My advice: Ignore it, because there's nothing you can do.

07  HTC: Here's the ad HTC hopes will convince people to buy their new flagship phone. Spoiler: Robert Downey Jr. talking for 62 (painful) seconds straight into the camera about design.

08  Huawei and Intel: The two have announced that they're going to tighten their R&D relationship and work together on "big data" solutions. No financial figures were mentioned.

09  Ineda Systems: Remember Sanjay Jha, the former CEO of Motorola Mobility? He's now chairman of a company (with 180+ engineers and $30 million in funding) that claims they've invented a chip that will enable wearable devices to last one month on a full charge. Re/code says we should see products using this chip in the next three to six months. It should be noted that Jha was a Qualcomm engineer, so he knows his stuff.

10  Intel: Starting April 15th, when Intel publishes their Q1 2014 financial results, the company will report revenues from their mobile division (chips for phones and tablets) separately. This is historic when you consider that Intel has been trying, for years, to break into the mobile device market.

11  Intel: They're going to shut down their "assembly and test operation in Costa Rica, eliminating 1,500 jobs."

12  LG: "LG has confirmed to Pocket-lint that its new LG G Watch, powered by Google's new Android Wear operating system, will be available before July and for less than £180 in the UK." Pocket-lint also has hands-on photos of the device, which is a first. Spoiler: It's ugly.

13  MediaFire: This Dropbox and Google Drive competitor just slashed the price of their cloud storage service to $5 per month for 1 TB.

14  MediaTek: Their Q1 2014 numbers are out. Revenues are up 91.9% year over year to $1.5 billion. If you don't know who MediaTek is, think of them as the Asian version of Qualcomm. Their chips may not be as good as Qualcomm's chips, but they're certainly good enough, and more importantly, they're far cheaper.

15  Netflix: They've officially started streaming 4K video. One Catch: You need a 2014 4K TV. If you're an early adopter, sorry.

16  Samsung: "Samsung India Electronics is looking to open 3,000-4,000 exclusive outlets across Indian towns with a population of less than 100,000."

17  Samsung: "Samsung sued Korean newspaper ET News for the equivalent of almost $300,000 U.S. dollars for writing a negative story about the camera on the Galaxy S5."

18  Samsung: Here are their four latest 30 second TV ads. Spoiler: Your iPad doesn't have multiple user support. Your iPad can't multitask. Your iPad has fewer pixels than my Galaxy Tab.

19  Samsung: They've updated the software on the Gear Fit, the smartwatch that has a long skinny flexible screen, to work vertically. This addresses the number one complaint about the device, which technically doesn't even launch until Friday.

20  Sesame Street: There's now a Netflix-like streaming service available for Sesame Street content. It's U.S. only and costs either $4/month or $30/year.

21  Sony: According to an update on Sony Mobile Hong Kong's Facebook page, the company's flagship phone, the Xperia Z2, isn't shipping until June. This was a device that was supposed to launch globally in April.

22  Sony: The updated version of Sony's mobile gaming device, the PS Vita, will come to the U.S. on May 6th for $200. Compared to the old Vita, the new one is significantly skinnier and also has better battery life.

23  StoreDot: This Israeli company got a lot of attention yesterday for demoing a smartphone battery that can fully recharge in 30 seconds. Why didn't I cover it? The founder of the company told the BBC that he'll "have a commercially ready device in three years." Translation: All we have is a rough prototype that's nowhere near ready for mass production.

24  Twitter: They're renaming the service to Facebook.

25  UK: "36% of people accessing the internet now do so via a tablet, according to UKOM and comScore, with UK tablet ownership growing 63% year on year in February 2014 to almost 18 million."

26  Xiaomi: They just sold 1.3 million phones in 12 hours to the tune of $242 million. If you still don't know why you should take Xiaomi seriously, Bloomberg wrote written a fantastic brief about the company yesterday.

The Real World

27  Afghanistan: "The Afghan election complaints commission says it has received more than 3,000 reports of violations of which around half will be investigated." Picking a new president isn't easy.

28  France: Ever wanted to know how much money the French government spends on protecting sheep from wolves and compensating farmers that have lost some of their flock? $16.6 million a year.

29  Hong Kong: A 15th century Chinese cup was sold at auction for $36 million. It's a new record for Chinese porcelain. The previous record, set in 2010, was $32.4 million. In other news, IKEA is holding a two for one sale on their $1 FÄRGRIK coffee mugs.

30  Malaysia: The team that originally "heard" the pings of the MH370 flight recorder say they've heard the pings again. Four pings in total have been picked up.

31  Toyota: They've just issued a recall affecting 6.4 million cars. They've identified five different issues in 27 of their models.

32  USA: "U.S. authorities have fined General Motors for failing to respond to requests for information about faulty ignition switches linked to 13 deaths. The car maker is being fined $7,000 a day until it complies with the request." Pocket change, sadly.

33  USA: You know those tiny Smart Cars? Four of them were found tipped over on Monday morning in one small California town. Seven people with nothing better to do with their time are to blame.

34  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: April 08: 45 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: Igloo, makers of an intranet you'll actually like, are happy to announce an OEM partnership with Swisscom. Under the trademark Dynamic Intranet, Swisscom will host and distribute Igloo's cloud intranet solution to their customers in Switzerland, Germany, and Italy. This offers Swisscom's European customers a state-of-the-art hosting facility in Zürich, while Igloo's North American and international customers continue to be hosted at CenturyLink facilities in Canada.

02  Adobe: Lightroom is now available for the iPad. "It requires the latest version of Lightroom 5 for Mac or PC (update available today) and a subscription to Adobe's Creative Cloud."

03  Apple: 9to5Mac has posted a WWDC preview that's incredibly comprehensive, though I question why they did so almost two months before the actual event. But I digress, all the iOS 8 and OS X 10.10 leaks and rumors currently out there are in this piece.

04  Apple: A former Apple Genius has published a detailed guide on how to increase the battery life of your iPhone. If you're having issues, and I know some of you are, then I hope this helps. Spoiler: Kill Facebook.

05  Apple: If you care about drama, here are some of the emails exchanged between Phil Schiller and Apple's ad agency over how they should deal with Samsung's rising success.

06  Cincinnati Bell: America's ninth largest wireless operator (roughly 340,000 subscribers) "will sell to Verizon all of its wireless spectrum licenses for $194 million in cash."

07  DigiTimes: "Apple reportedly plans to form a R&D team to develop baseband processors for use in iPhones to be released in 2015." The baseband, often called the modem, is the thing that enables your mobile phone to connect to your mobile operator. It's easily one of the most complicated parts of a device.

08  DigiTimes: "Microsoft reportedly has been aggressively trying to persuade MediaTek to push Windows-based tablets in China's white-box market." Note that the Surface RT and all of Nokia's Lumia phones use chips from MediaTek's biggest competitor, Qualcomm.

09  Foxconn: The company that makes iPads and iPhones for Apple allegedly wants to spend $2 billion to buy a Chinese cable company that has 1.2 million customers. Foxconn's end goal is to eventually produce content.

10  Google: Registration for Google I/O 2014 has been pushed back by a week. It was supposed to take place today. I'm assuming Google isn't done testing their new ticketing system, which is based on a lottery.

11  Google: The WSJ says "Google struck a licensing deal that will give it access to technology from hotel-booking-software start-up Room 77 while increasing the size of its hotel-search team. Among those who reported for work at Google today was Calvin Yang, Room 77's co-founder and chief technology officer." No financial figures were mentioned.

12  HTC: Their Q1 2014 numbers are out. Nutshell: $62.06 million in the red.

13  HTC: There will be a "Stealth Red" version of the HTC One M8. The company accidentally started advertising it on Google. No photos, sadly.

14  Huawei: A Slovakian Android website says Huawei will be hosting an event in Paris on May 7th to unveil their latest flagship phone. They say Huawei has confirmed the event with them.

15  Megaupload: Six movie studios are suing Megaupload, they want $175 million (total).

16  Microsoft: Today's the day. Windows XP is dead. Not really, but everyone will say that anyway.

17  Nokia: Deep in this article about the alleged future of Windows Phone is this nugget: "I've also heard rumblings of a dual-lens phone from Nokia later this year, where two cameras would be used perhaps for a multi-focus, Lytro type effect." HTC's M8 has two cameras, so Nokia going the dual-camera route wouldn't be that insane.

18  Nokia: They published a press release this morning saying China has approved the Microsoft deal. No word as to which countries haven't said yes yet, but most people think it's India.

19  Qualcomm: They announced two flagship 64-bit Snapdragon chips, the 808 and 810. Both are very unorthodox in that they use ARM designed application processors instead of Qualcomm's own in-house APs. They're also not going to ship until 2015.

20  Samsung: "Samsung Gear Solo" will allegedly be the product name for a new Samsung smartwatch that features a SIM card slot. Said watch is rumored to be a Korea only product.

21  Samsung: A ton of Galaxy S5 reviews have gone live today. I'm sure they're all good, but this one is the best.

22  Samsung: SamMobile has published the full specifications of a high-end 10.5 inch tablet that Samsung will soon announce. What makes this tablet special is that it has an AMOLED display. No photos, but expect this thing to look like a giant Galaxy S5.

23  Samsung: The Galaxy Ace Style is official. It's a low end 4.0 inch phone running the latest version of Android. No price, but Samsung says it'll ship globally starting this month.

24  Samsung: They expect to "make an operating profit of $7.9 billion for the January-to-March quarter, down 4% from the same period last year. This follows a 6% decline in operating profit in the previous quarter."

25  Seagate: They unveiled a $600 6 TB hard drive. It's meant for enterprises, but still, you have to marvel that 6 TB hard drives are now a thing.

26  Skype: They've announced something called Skype TX, which is "an easy-to-use hardware and software combination" meant for broadcasters or people "within in a studio environment." Translation: A (hopefully) better version of Skype for professionals.

27  SoftBank: Forbes is reporting that if SoftBank fails to merge Sprint and T-Mobile, they might start buying up European operators.

28  Twitter: They spent an undisclosed amount of money on custom Android lock screen maker "Cover". What makes "Cover" special? Depending on your location and/or time of day, different application shortcuts are displayed on your screen.

29  Uber: The car hire service is expanding into the courier business, but only in Manhattan. The new service is called Uber RUSH and costs between $15 to $30, depending on distance.

30  WhatsApp: There's now a "WhatsApp" prepaid SIM in Germany that basically gives you free WhatsApp service, regardless of the balance on the SIM. Data is incredibly pricey at 0.24 Euros per megabyte, but if you pay 10 Euros a month, you get 600 "units", where a unit is either one megabyte of data or one SMS or one minute of calling. The SIM is powered by E-Plus.

The Real World

31  Australia: Raija Ogden was competing in a triathlon when a drone that was recording the event fell out of the sky from a height of 10 meters (32 feet) and hit her in the head. She's fine, and she says it could've been a lot worse, specifically saying the drone could have fallen on a small child in the crowd.

32  Europe: Scientists studying nearly 32,000 bee colonies in 17 EU countries have come to the conclusion that the rate of mortality of Northern European bees is off the charts. There's a 33.6% chance that a bee in Belgium will not survive the winter. In the UK, it's 28.8%. In Sweden, it's 28.7%. One normally expects a death rate of 10%.

33  Germany: Remember that guy that had over 1,400 pieces of art stolen by the Nazis in his apartment? He's finally agreed to let investigators try and find the rightful owners of said art, which is estimated to to be worth $1.35 billion, and then return it to them.

34  Japan and Australia: The two countries have signed a trade deal after seven years of negations. There are a lot of bullet points, but here's the one sentence summary: Japan will pay less import taxes on Australian beef and cheese, and Australia will pay less import taxes on Japanese gizmos and cars.

35  Poland: Artur Debski is a Polish politician that wants to find out why his country's young people are leaving en masse to find jobs in the UK, so he's decided to do what they do. He's coming to the UK to find a job via a job center and plans to live on $165 a week to see just how the British system works so he can bring it to Poland.

36  Space: Scientists studying the birth of the universe have discovered that "three billion years after the Big Bang, the cosmos was pushing itself apart by another 1% every 44 million years."

37  Taiwan: Students took over Taiwan's parliament building in the middle of March to protest the country's economic ties with China. They've been occupying the building this whole time. The students just announced that they'll be leaving on Thursday.

38  Ukraine: "Rebels occupying Donetsk's regional government building declared a 'people's republic' on Monday and called for a referendum on secession from Ukraine to be held by 11 May." Crimea 2.0?

39  USA: "Four paralyzed men have been able to move their legs for the first time in years after electrical stimulation of their spinal cords, US doctors report." These guys aren't walking, but they're at least able to move their limbs, albeit in an uncontrolled fashion.

40  USA: "Petrol-sniffing spiders have forced Mazda to issue a voluntary recall notice so it can apply a software fix to its cars. The yellow sac spider is attracted to the smell of petrol, and will weave its web in engines, causing a blockage and build-up of pressure." This affects roughly 42,000 cars.

41  USA: Remember that train derailment in New York in December 2013 that killed four people? The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) released a report on Monday saying the driver of that train, William Rockefeller, suffers from "severe obstructive sleep apnoea". Translation: He dozed at the wheel.

42  USA: The Washington mudslide death toll has reached 33; 10 people are still missing.

43  Venezuela: The death toll from the protests now stands at 39.

44  World: "Global investment in renewables fell by 14% during 2013, but the percentage of electricity generated by renewable sources still grew." Also good news: "Renewables accounted for 43.6% of newly installed generation capacity in 2013." By the way, this data is from The United Nations, so it's solid.

45  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: April 07: 42 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: Igloo has some exciting news to announce – tomorrow.

02  Amazon: They've unveiled a WiFi enabled stick that has a microphone and a barcode scanner. When you're out of toilet paper, milk, toothpaste, whatever, either say the name or scan the barcode of said item and it'll automatically be ordered. Note that to receive said stick, which is called the "Dash", you have to be personally selected by Amazon themselves, as well as be a user of Amazon Fresh.

03  Apple: An internal slide dating back to April 2013 was released thanks to the Apple/Samsung trial. It's titled "Consumers want what we don't have" and shows Apple fully understands that the growth of the mobile phone market comes from sub $300 products and phones with screens larger than 4.0 inches.

04  ASUS: Photos of an unreleased Chromebook from ASUS have appeared online. This is semi-noteworthy because ASUS hasn't entered the Chromebook game yet.

05  comScore: People love when comScore publishes fresh data on the U.S. smartphone market, so here's a link to their latest numbers. Spoiler: Apple has more market share (41.3%), than the number two (Samsung at 27.0%), three (LG at 6.8%), and four (Motorola at 6.3%) players combined.

06  Google: $1.4 million. That's how big of a fine Google received "over complaints that cars it used to record images on Italian streets in 2010 were not clearly recognizable."

07  Google: Android Police says Google is working on something called "Hera", which aims to give "apps" written in HTML the same kind of power that native Android apps have. The article is light on details, but I'm going to assume we'll hear more about this at Google I/O on June 25th. It should be noted that Sundar Pichai, the guy in charge of Chrome, also took over Android in March 2013.

08  Google: Billboard says Google's Spotify clone has been delayed to Q2 or later. They say Google has all the content deals, that's not the problem, the problem is that Google isn't done with the product. Note that Google already has a Spotify clone called Google Play Music All Access, so it's not clear what this new service, powered by YouTube, will provide.

09  Google: The Verge has obtained information and images of something called "Android TV". As far as I can tell, it's just a clone of Amazon's new Fire TV product that was unveiled last week. Android TV will allegedly launch "soon", and not much else is known.

10  IBM: "The IBM mainframe is celebrating its 50th anniversary. The first System 360 mainframe was unveiled on 7 April 1964."

11  Indonesia: All phones sold in Indonesia are taxed at a rate of 7.5%. The country is thinking about bumping that up to 20% for phones that cost more than $440.

12  Internet Companies: Reuters polled roughly 5,000 Americans between March 11th and March 16th and discovered that over half of them (51%) said Google, Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Microsoft, and Twitter were "pushing too far and expanding into too many areas of people's lives." Another fun number: 27% think Google's "Don't Be Evil" slogan is total BS.

13  Lenovo: The company that took Motorola off Google's hands has just bought 3,800 patents from NEC, some of which are considered essential for 3G and LTE. No price tag was given.

14  Microsoft: A five year old boy discovered a bug in the XBOX Live online gaming service that let him log into his father's account simply by using a password full of spaces. Conveniently, the boy's father is a security researcher. He reached out to Microsoft, who then thanked the boy and gave him four free games.

15  Microsoft: Bloomberg says Microsoft has commissioned six television shows that will only be available to XBOX customers. Said shows will start airing in June. No word as to how much they cost to make.

16  Microsoft: They unveiled a concept of what can best be described as an Apple CarPlay clone. Unlike CarPlay, which has a rough ship date and a list of partners, "Windows in the Car" is just a pretty slideshow right now.

17  Pakistan: "A Pakistani Christian couple have been sentenced to death for blasphemy after allegedly sending a text message insulting the Prophet Muhammad."

18  Samsung: "At least five high-ranking executives from Samsung's US mobile business -- known as Samsung Telecommunications America, or STA -- have left the company or have given their notice over the past two months, people familiar with the departures told CNET."

19  Samsung: As expected, the company unveiled a dual-SIM version of the Galaxy S5 for China. Watch it also come to India, Russia, and other markets where dual-SIM is popular over the next few months.

20  Samsung: The company's 2014 flagship phone, the Galaxy S5, has a silly door covering the USB port. It's going to annoy tens of millions of people, guaranteed. Here are the official replacement battery door covers that add wireless charging.

21  Turkey: "A Turkish court on Friday ruled that a blanket ban of social-media website YouTube violated human rights and ordered most of the restrictions be lifted." Wait, access to YouTube is a human right?

22  Twitter: According to the WSJ, Twitter "will debut 15 types of new ad products and improved ways to target users over the next six months." The first of those ad products, applications ads, have already been seen by some users.

23  USA: Remember that Cuban version of Twitter that was allegedly designed by the United States government? The U.S. government has confirmed that yes, they were indeed behind the service.

24  Waze: "A blog post on LinkedIn from Noam Bardin, who is CEO and co-founder of Waze, confirms that Google agreed to a $1.15 billion deal to buy the company." This is the first time the Waze acquisition figure has been made public.

25  Yahoo!: The WSJ says Yahoo! is close to ordering four television shows to be made, each with 10 episodes, with each episode being 30 minutes long and costing "from $700,000 to a few million dollars". No word as to when said shows, which technically aren't even real yet, will air.

The Real World

26  Afghanistan: The country just had their first presidential election. Usually people who want to take control of Afghanistan use tanks and/or guns, so this is historic. Of the 12 million people eligible to vote, roughly seven million actually did, with one third of them being women. Results are expected to be announced in a few days.

27  Africa: Nigeria has officially surpassed South Africa to become the country with the largest economy in Africa. That being said, South Africa has a GDP-per-capita that's three times higher than that of Nigeria.

28  Australia: There are two versions of tobacco. The pretty version, and the version that gets turned into cigarettes. Scientists have discovered the pretty version produces a chemical called "NaD1" that can "fight off fungal and bacterial infections". The researchers want to test this chemical on human cancer patients, but it should be stressed that it'll be at least a decade until this stuff becomes a commercial product.

29  Germany: "A team of engineers in Germany has produced a bionic kangaroo, capable of jumping and then recovering its balance." It weighs seven kilograms, it's one meter tall, and can jump 40 centimeters into the air. This isn't an article, it's a one minute video.

30  India: The country's general election, officially the world's largest, has just begun. There are 814 million potential voters. The vote is so massive that it's being split over nine days, with the final votes due to be counted on May 16.

31  Malaysia: "An Australian vessel searching for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane has detected signals consistent with those from aircraft black boxes."

32  Rwanda: They're going to "start a week of official mourning to mark the 20th anniversary of the country's genocide." 800,000 people were killed in 100 days. Sadly, the Rwandan Genocide doesn't really get a lot of attention, just like Syria, because hey, it's so far away, and we don't have economic ties with them, right?

33  Space: Enceladus, one of Saturn's moons, apparently has a body of water the size of Lake Michigan. Key quote, from UK Professor Andrew Coates: "I think Enceladus has gone to the top of the charts in terms of a place where there could be life."

34  UK: 15 million tons. That's how much food the UK throws away every year. The EU total is 90 million tons. It's easy to blame consumers, but this article points out that the relationship between supermarkets and their suppliers should also be examined.

35  UK: Sales of over the counter HIV tests are now legal. Unfortunately, no one is selling them yet due to EU regulations. That's expected to change either by the end of this year or early 2015. An estimated 25,000 people are living with HIV in the UK and don't know it.

36  UK: The UK's Ministry of Defense has a new robot called "The Porton Man" that costs over $1.82 million, has more than 100 sensors inside its body, and will be used primarily for developing "the next generation of CB (chemical and biological) protective suit equipment." It also looks terrifying.

37  Ukraine: Darth Vader will not be allowed to compete in the May 25th presidential election.

38  Ukraine: Donetsk, Luhansk, and Kharkiv are three cities in East Ukraine that are starting to look like they're going to be the next Crimea. Protestors in those cities have broken into government buildings, raised Russian flags, and are demanding a referendum on independence.

39  Ukraine: The country is used to paying $268.50 for 1,000 cubic meters of natural gas. Russia just raised that price by 81% to $485.50. Ukraine's response? Refuse to pay Russia and bring them to court if necessary.

40  USA: Former President George W. Bush has a hobby that I personally never knew he had: Painting. This past Saturday, he showcased over 24 portraits of some of the world leaders he's met.

41  USA: Remember that Chicago train derailment? Turns out the driver, age 25, fell asleep at the wheel. She's been fired.

42  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: April 04: 40 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: About one year ago, Google announced they were going to kill Google Reader. Now if you don't know what RSS is, then I can't adequately explain to you why that day was tragic. I immediately spent the next few weeks and months testing every RSS reader under the sun to find a suitable replacement, and I'm proud to say that I have: NewsBlur. Without NewsBlur, this website, and my enjoyment of the internet, would simply not be be possible.

02  Apple: "Apple quietly acquired an automatic speech recognition (ASR) technology company called Novauris Technologies, which grew out of Dragon Systems R&D U.K. Ltd., the British research subsidiary of Dragon Systems." No financial figures were mentioned.

03  Apple: WWDC dates have officially been announced: June 02 to 06.

04  Cyanogen: The company that's trying to turn their custom Android ROM into a legit business has rebranded themselves. Their new logo should be familiar to fans of the 1987 cult classic "RoboCop".

05  Europe: The European Parliament has voted to eliminate roaming fees effective December 2015. They're also forcing all European ISPs to abide by net neutrality principles.

06  Facebook: "Facebook's Messenger app has today added free audio calls on WiFi (VoIP) for all users [Note: That means Android and iOS] in all countries."

07  Facebook: $1.5 million. That's how much money Facebook awarded to security researchers in 2013 for submitting critical bugs.

08  Firechat: That iOS chat app that's been getting a lot of attention because it lets you talk to people using only Bluetooth and WiFi is now available for Android.

09  Flickr: Mark Spiering, Flickr's Head of Product, has left to become Head of Product at Berlin based EyeEm. They essentially make a Flickr clone that's mobile only. EyeEm's app has been downloaded over 10 million times.

10  Google: According to an article on The Information that's behind a paywall, Google has talked to Verizon about the possibility of launching an MVNO in areas where Google has deployed Google Fiber. I'm going to assume Google wants to do this so they can offer what the industry calls a "triple play" package. One bill, three services: Internet, TV, Phone.

11  Google: The "Google Opinion Rewards" app, which gives you Play Store credit in return for answering surveys, is now available in Canada, the United Kingdom, and Australia. Before it was U.S. only.

12  Google: The United States Patent and Trademark Office is refusing to give Google a trademark on the word "Glass". Here's the scary part: "Trademark attorneys for Google, Anne Peck and Katie Krajeck from Cooley LLP, wrote back to the trademark office examiner two weeks ago with a 1,928-page letter in defense of the application." How heavy was that envelope?

13  Google: They've uploaded a three and a half minute video showing off Project Ara, which is an attempt to create a modular mobile phone. Personally, I have very little faith in this ever becoming a retail product.

14  Imgur: The center of the internet meme universe has just raised $40 million.

15  Journalism: New research from Pew says revenues generated by American journalism have declined by one third since 2006. That being said, the percentage of people paying for news has increased from 16% in 2006 to 24% today.

16  Microsoft: On April 14th, Microsoft will allegedly publish a Windows Phone 8.1 Developer Preview that just about any Windows Phone owner will be able to install. I'm going to recommend you just wait for an official over-the-air update instead of potentially breaking your phone.

17  Microsoft: The company has tweeted that Office for iPad has been downloaded over 12 million times.

18  Mozilla: The CEO of Mozilla has resigned because of all the controversy over his 2008 donation to a political campaign seeking to ban gay marriage in the U.S. state of California.

19  Nest: Sales of the Nest smoke and carbon monoxide detector have been halted due to a bug that lets users unintentionally disable the device.

20  Samsung: Some athlete was paid a lot of money to promote a Samsung phone. Said athlete used his Samsung phone to take a selfie with the President of the United States. Said selfie went viral. According to the WSJ, the White House is furious about this.

21  Samsung: The company accidentally showed off a smartphone that hasn't been announced yet, the Galaxy Ace Style. It's a low end budget Android 4.4 device with a 4.0 inch screen.

22  Samsung: The Samsung ATIV SE is now official. It's a Galaxy S4 that runs Windows Phone.

23  Samsung: They're relaunching the Galaxy S III in India. Reminder: It's a two year old phone.

24  Turkey: The Twitter ban has been lifted. The YouTube ban, however, is still in place.

25  USA: You know how everyone likes to talk about the broken American patent system and how it should be fixed? Apple, Microsoft, and IBM, among other companies, are now working together to make sure nothing changes.

26  Vine: Twitter's six second video sharing service now supports direct (aka private) messaging.

27  VKontakte: Russia's version of Facebook is facing legal action from Sony, Universal, and Warner Music, over a service they offer that gives Russians access to unlicensed music. This isn't the first time this has happened. "In November 2012, VK was found guilty by the Russian Supreme Court of distributing unlicensed music belonging to the Gala Music Group."

28  Yelp: Those reviews that you read on Yelp, ever stop and wonder if some of them aren't actually legitimate? This WSJ article makes for a fascinating read, and it has this startling data point: "Yelp said it receives roughly six subpoenas monthly, some of which seek the names of anonymous users."

29  ZunZuneo: That's the name of a Cuban version of Twitter that was secretly created by the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID). It apparently had 400,000 users at its peak. ZunZuneo is Cuban slang for the noise a hummingbird makes.

The Real World

30  China: This 49 second shows a Chinese street vendor making popcorn in a rather peculiar way. Spoiler: His popcorn machine doubles as a cannon.

31  Europe: With a sample size of 3,955 people spread out over nine European countries, the International Agency for Research on Cancer has discovered that not regularly seeing a dentist puts you at a higher risk of developing oral cancer. Sounds obvious, right? On the flip side, they also discovered that people who regularly use mouthwash are also at a higher risk for developing oral cancer.

32  Indonesia: The government will "pay $1.8 million in blood money to prevent an Indonesian maid being executed in Saudi Arabia." Said maid hit her employer in 2007 so hard that she slipped into a coma and died. The maid says she was constantly abused, hence the attack.

33  Nigeria: Lamido Sanusi, Nigeria's Bank Chief, caused a bit of a ruckus when he reported that $20 billion of the country's oil revenues are missing. He had his passport confiscated and he's been harassed, so he filed a complaint. Result? $300,000 compensation. Sadly, that $20 billion is still missing.

34  UK: "An accumulating body of evidence supports a link between urban green space and benefits to human wellbeing." Translation: People feel better when they're near nature.

35  Ukraine: "Ukraine's special police were behind the killings of dozens of anti-government protesters in Kiev in February, a government inquiry says. Interior Minister Arsen Avakov told reporters that 12 members of the Berkut police had been identified as snipers and arrested."

36  USA: For the first time since January 2007, not a single American soldier has died in Afghanistan for a given calendar month. Let's hope future months will be as good as March.

37  USA: NASA has published a statement on Google+ that basically says they're not going to work with Russia anymore. Note that this does not apply to NASA's commitments to the International Space Station.

38  USA: The death toll from the Washington mudslide now stands at 30; 13 people are still missing.

39  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

40  One more thing: Tradition dictates I remind you Tab Dump via email exists on Friday.

item.title: April 03: 48 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: About one year ago, Google announced they were going to kill Google Reader. Now if you don't know what RSS is, then I can't adequately explain to you why that day was tragic. I immediately spent the next few weeks and months testing every RSS reader under the sun to find a suitable replacement, and I'm proud to say that I have: NewsBlur. Without NewsBlur, this website, and my enjoyment of the internet, would simply not be be possible.

02  Podcast: James Whatley and I sat down for 37 minutes this morning for our weekly mobile focused tech podcast. We spent the first 20 minutes talking about all of yesterday's Microsoft and Nokia news.

03  Amazon: They launched a $99 Android powered Apple TV clone in the United States that features a remote control which can perform voice searches.  For an additional $40, Amazon will also sell you a videogame controller.

04  Apple: It's not every day you get to see snippets of the emails Steve Jobs sent to his colleagues. The WSJ has two. One says Apple is in a "Holy War" with Android. Another says Apple is in danger of developing a case of the innovator's dilemma.

05  AT&T: They're going to "hire more than 3,000 retail sales and sales management employees nationwide over the next several months."

06  Bolivia: The country's first telecommunications satellite, valued at $300 million, is now live. President Evo Morales says his people can expect their mobile phone bills to fall by 20%.

07  Coolpad: This Chinese handset maker, which is almost as big as Lenovo in China, plans to sell 60 million smartphones in 2014, with 20 million of those being from their new online store that was built in partnership with JD.com.

08  Google: According to leaked slides obtained by Android Police, Google is planning a premium Android retail experience for U.S. wireless operator stores called "Android Silver". To be in this program, device makers need to make hardware that "runs the latest version of Android with no or very limited customizations". Google will also offer 24x7 support to people who buy "Android Silver" devices. Said support will work in much the same way as Amazon's Mayday service, meaning someone can take over your Android phone and help you. A launch date for "Android Silver" was not mentioned.

09  Google: They're testing a completely new look for their Gmail mobile app. Here are two leaked screenshots of the Android version. Note that the iOS version will probably look very similar.

10  Intel: They've notoriously had difficulty getting tablet and smartphone makers to use their chips, so they've just announced a $100 million Chinese investment fund that aims to change companies' minds.

11  Intel: They've released a 64-bit version of Android that unsurprisingly only works on Intel chips.

12  Italy: ANICA, Italy's version of the MPAA, will launch a video on demand service to combat piracy. At launch, only 350 titles will be available, but it's expected that this will be the premier service for Italian film. The price of the service was not mentioned.

13  Microsoft: Remember that Microsoft employee that leaked products to that French blogger and started the whole Microsoft/Hotmail/privacy scandal? Three months of jail time and a $22,500 fine.

14  Microsoft: The company held a three hour keynote yesterday. I highly recommend you watch The Verge's seven minute supercut. Here are the main highlights: Windows Phone 8.1 is official. It comes with a notification shade, which looks exactly like the one in Android. It has an Apple Siri and Google Now clone called Cortana. It also has a swipe enabled keyboard, and you can finally set a background photo. Windows 8.1 Update 1 is official too. It'll make Windows more keyboard friendly when it ships on April 8th. Microsoft also demoed "the next version of Windows", and I'm happy to report the start bar is back. On top of that, the company showed off a preview of touch enabled Office, though they failed to provide a ship date. But the biggest announcement, bar none, is that Windows Phone is now free for OEMs, as is Windows 8.1, but only on tablets with a 9.0 inch or smaller screen.

15  Motorola: The Moto G Forte is official. It's not a Moto G variant, as people originally believed, it's just a Moto G with a bundled Grip Shell case.

16  Nest: Google's latest acquisition is now selling their wares in the UK for £180.

17  Nokia: They announced three Windows Phone 8.1 handsets during Microsoft's three hour keynote yesterday. The Lumia 930, Lumia 635, and Lumia 630. The Lumia 930 is the international version of the Verizon Wireless Lumia Icon. That means 5.0 inch 1080p display, top of the line everything, 20 megapixel camera. It ships in June for $599 before tax. The Lumia 630 comes in two versions: single SIM ($159) and dual SIM ($169). It has a 4.5 inch 854 x 480 pixel screen, quad core processor, 512 MB of RAM, and a 5 MP camera. The Lumia 635 ($189) is a Lumia 630, but with 4G LTE. Both the Lumia 630 and 635 ship in May.

18  Samsung: According to SamMobile, who is almost never wrong, the Galaxy S5 Mini will have a 4.5 inch 720p display, 1.5 GB of RAM, and an 8 megapixel camera. No pics. No price. No availability information.

19  Turkey: The country's highest court has ruled the ban on Twitter is illegal. Not that it matters, the government does whatever they want.

20  Twitter: They now support emoji.

21  UK: "Vodafone has said it will create 1,400 jobs by opening 150 new shops in 2014."

22  Ukraine: There's an app called "Boycott the Occupiers" that's been installed by over 50,000 Ukrainians. It lets users scan products to determine whether or not they were made in Russia.

23  USB: The first images (technically renders) of USB's answer to Apple's Lightning connector are out. Note that you shouldn't expect to see devices with this connector until Q4 2014 at the earliest.

24  Wearables: According to research from Endeavour Partners, "one-third of American consumers who have owned a wearable product stopped using it within six months" and "half of U.S. consumers who have owned a modern activity tracker no longer use it". Their sample size was "thousands" of 18+ year old Americans, and they collected their data in September 2013.

25  Xiaomi: They're going to sell an accessory you can plug into your device's headphone jack, giving your phone or tablet another physical button. No price. No date.

26  Yahoo!: They published a blog post saying everything that touches their servers is now encrypted. "Our broader mission is to not only make Yahoo! secure, but improve the security of the overall web ecosystem."

The Real World

27  Australia: Six people have died because of shark attacks during the past three years, which has prompted the government to "order a cull of sharks". No word as to how many sharks they want to kill.

28  China: In a bid to boost the Chinese economy, the government has announced that there will be an "18% increase in the total number of railway lines being built compared to last year." Said increase in railroad infrastructure will cost $24.6 billion.

29  Europe: "Electric and hybrid cars will have to generate noise to make them safer for pedestrians, especially the visually impaired, the European Parliament says." Assuming the law gets passed, all 2019 model hybrids and electrics sold in Europe must generate noise. And all electric and hybrid cars, regardless of age, must make a noise by 2021.

30  Europe: "The biggest civil Earth-observation program ever conceived begins its roll-out on Thursday with the launch of a radar satellite from French Guiana." The Copernicus project is essentially a complex weather monitoring system consisting of six satellites. Total price: $10.3 billion.

31  Germany: Starting in 2015, Germany might have their first ever minimum wage law: 8.50 Euros ($11.70) per hour. Angela Merkel approved the proposal, but it still has to go through parliament and the upper house. A decision isn't expected until September.

32  Hong Kong: The average person in Hong Kong consumes 70 kilograms of fish every year, 10 times as much as the average American. The BBC has profiled Oceanethix, a local fish farm that's unique because they operate on the 15th floor of a tall building. They own 11 tanks and sell two tons of fish every week.

33  Ireland: Some idiot forgot to push the time on his watch up an hour. He used said watch to program a bomb. Said bomb blew up in his face.

34  Israel: Researchers have discovered oxytocin, often called "the love hormone", makes people lie. The study is questionable, however, and without knowing the sample size, it's nearly impossible for me to call this conclusive.

35  Italy: Two paintings were stolen from London in 1970 by three men who then left the art on a train. The train company sold the paintings at a lost property auction in 1975 for $32. The son of the man that bought the paintings noticed that one of them might be a Gauguin. He was right. Police recovered the paintings, which are estimated to cost $14.6 million total.

36  Russia: They're pissed that NATO is building up their military presence in Eastern Europe. Then again, who wouldn't be upset with 10 American F-15 fighter jets ready to attack?

37  Saudi Arabia: Archaeologists have found a 2.25 meter (7.4 foot) long elephant tusk in the middle of the desert. They say it's 325,000 years old and is proof positive that the desert was once a "lush and fertile plain". They also say the tusk would have belonged to a six ton elephant, compared to today's three ton elephants.

38  South Africa: "South Africa's government will distribute colored and flavored condoms among students to end 'condom fatigue', the health minister has said." Normal condoms are apparently not "cool enough", so much so that condom use is dropping and the number of people contracting HIV is rising.

39  Uganda: "Private clinics in Uganda's capital, Kampala, are selling fake HIV negative certificates to help people get jobs." How much is one of these certificates? $20.

40  UK: A small trial (28 people), performed by the Oxford Health Foundation, has revealed that the "party drug" Ketamine can cure depression, even in people who have been suffering for decades.

41  USA: "An exchange student fell to his death after ingesting marijuana in Colorado - the first death linked to the drug since it was legalized in the U.S. state." Levy Thamba was 19 years old and from The Republic of Congo.

42  USA: "Fire-fighting robots designed to withstand intense heat are to be tested by the US Navy this summer." Said robots are five feet tall (1.5 meters) and were built by several universities working together.

43  USA: 110 million years ago, two dinosaurs were running in a riverbed in Texas. 70 years ago, that 45 meter riverbed was dug up, split into chunks, and photographed. This week, that research was finally fed into a computer, which then spit out a 3D map.

44  USA: The death toll from the Washington mudslide now stands at 29, with 20 people still missing.

45  USA: The U.S. Supreme Court has abolished limits on political contributions. There used to be a rule that said individuals can't donate more than $123,200. That's no longer the case. There is, however, still a limit on how much one person can donate to one particular candidate: $2,600.

46  USA: There's been another shooting at Fort Hood. Four people are confirmed dead. The gunman is one of those four people. While not as bad as the 2009 shooting that left 13 people dead, neither of these incidents should have occurred in the first place.

47  USA: Two decades ago, researchers at the University of Minnesota performed cognitive tests on 3,000 people with an average age of 25 years old. Said 3,000 people have now been retested, and it turns out those who regularly engaged in cardiovascular exercise performed "better at tests of memory and thinking skills".

48  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: April 02: 36 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: About one year ago, Google announced they were going to kill Google Reader. Now if you don't know what RSS is, then I can't adequately explain to you why that day was tragic. I immediately spent the next few weeks and months testing every RSS reader under the sun to find a suitable replacement, and I'm proud to say that I have: NewsBlur. Without NewsBlur, this website, and my enjoyment of the internet, would simply not be be possible.

02  ABI Research: These analysts say "an estimated 2.1 million Chromebooks shipped in 2013 with nearly 89% of total shipments reaching North America." Average selling price: $338. They predict 11 million Chromebooks will ship in 2019, but I wouldn't take a prediction that's five years out very seriously.

03  Amazon: You can now use their lockers (how many of them exist?) to return unwanted items.

04  Apple: Rumor has it that "Apple is in talks with Japan's Renesas Electronics to take over a unit that designs chips for smartphone displays." Said unit costs $479 million and has 240 employees.

05  Apple: You can now buy ads on iAd using just your Apple ID. Before you were required to be registered as an app developer.

06  BlackBerry: T-Mobile USA will stop selling BlackBerry products effective April 25th.

07  BlackBerry: Their chat app has been updated. It now supports stickers, sharing images with groups, and 16 megabyte file attachments. Unfortunately, only 85 million people use BBM. Anything below 100 million in the messaging space is considered niche.

08  Flurry Analytics: There are a ton of data points in Flurry's latest blog post, but here are the two that stand out: 86% of the time people spend on their phones is spent using apps, the rest is spent in the web browser. And the average time an American spends using a phone every day has gone up four minutes compared to last year, it's now 2 hours and 42 minutes.

09  Google: According to one of Engadget's trusted sources, Google will launch a completely overhauled camera app soon that will be able to run on any Android device (as opposed to just Nexus hardware) running 4.4 KitKat and above. Said camera app will also let developers write their own extensions, similar to how Windows Phone uses the "Lens" concept.

10  Google: The latest Android platform figures are out. Key highlights: 5.3% of devices that have access to the Play Store are running the latest version of Android. 17.8% are still on Android 2.3 Gingerbread, which launched in December 2010.

11  Intel: They just dropped $19.2 million on Inside Secure's next generation NFC modem. No word as to when NFC will actually become useful.

12  Lenovo: They announced four new tablets, two with 7.0 inch screens, one with an 8.0 screen, and finally a 10.0 incher. They'll all hit the UK, and presumably Europe, this quarter. The key selling point of all of them is that they have front firing speakers.

13  LINE: My favorite chat app now has 400 million users.

14  LinkedIn: They're trying to get a Chrome extension called "Sell Hack" off the internet. What does it do? Show you the hidden email addresses of LinkedIn users.

15  Mozilla: CNET sat down with Mozilla's new CEO and talked about the gay marriage issue at length. If you care about how Brendan Eich spends his money, then this is for you. Personally, I just want to see Firefox become a competitive product again, because right now it's a joke.

16  Samsung: They announced three new tablets, each called the Galaxy Tab4. One has a 7.0 inch screen, another has an 8.0 inch screen, and the last has a 10.1 inch screen. All three have the same specs: 1.2 GHz quad core processor, 1280 x 800 pixel screen, Android 4.4 KitKat, and a 3 megapixel camera. No prices, and they launch this quarter.

17  Spotify: Alexander Kubaneishvili is leaving Google after 2.5 years with the company to help Spotify launch in Russia in H2 2014. Spotify also has plans to launch in Brazil at roughly the same time.

18  Spotify: They redesigned all their apps. Said apps launch today.

19  UK: The CEO of Three UK told The Telegraph that he's not interested in merging or buying O2 UK. He was asked this because Three Ireland purchased O2 Ireland.

20  USA: T-Mobile has the fastest 4G LTE network in the USA according to tests conducted by OpenSignal. That's the headline everyone is more or less writing. The thing is, that same research showed a T-Mobile device is connected to 4G LTE just 61.1% of the time it's on, versus 70.6% for AT&T, and a massive 83.2% for Verizon.

21  USA: The state of Florida has proposed legislation (that will probably not pass) which will put people caught texting and driving in jail for 30 years.

22  WhatsApp: They've announced a new daily record: "20B messages sent (inbound) and 44B messages received (outbound) by our users = 64B messages handled in just 24 hours."

The Real World

23  Australia: Philip Morris will stop making cigarettes in Australia. 180 people will become unemployed. Why? Because in 2012, the government passed plain packaging laws, which made all cigarette packs look the same, regardless of vendor.

24  Gambia: This 90 second video features Tom Williams from the Legs for Africa project showing off his van full of 500 prosthetic legs that will be shipped from the UK to Gambia. It's not every day you see a van filled to the brim with fake legs. Magic legs.

25  Germany: "Germany's labor ministry has banned managers from calling or emailing staff out of hours except in emergencies." Work life balance, it's not just a theory, it's the law.

26  Japan: "The first group of Fukushima evacuees have returned to their homes, three years after the disaster at the nuclear power plant." Roughly 350 people have been allowed to return; 80,000 people in total were evacuated.

27  Japan: The scientist that earlier this year said she discovered how to turn red blood cells into stem cells has been found guilty of misconduct. "The Riken Centre panel said Dr Haruko Obokata fabricated her work in an intentionally misleading fashion."

28  North Korea: Here are two photos of a North Korean drone that landed in South Korea. Said drone was used to photograph military installations and the presidential compound.

29  Scotland: Keane Wallis-Bennett, age 12, died because one of the walls in her school collapsed. Said school was built in 1959. Devon Blyth, age 13, said she complained about that wall being "wobbly" for months, but the teachers ignored her.

30  Ukraine: There are people in the Ukraine spending their free time trying to put together the documents that the government shredded before they lost control. They have a website called "Yanukovych Leaks". So far they've found nothing.

31  USA: 60 minutes, which used to be considered the beacon of American journalism, has apologized for adding pre-recorded engine noise to Sunday's episode about Tesla and their electric cars.

32  USA: Benito Flores, age 43, remains missing a day after he was swept out to sea during an ocean baptism.

33  USA: DARPA has launched a new Biological Technologies Office that will work on things such as "internet-enabled prosthetics, memory restoration, and body suits that enable soldiers to carry lots of weight." DARPA invented the internet, so there's a reason to be excited about this.

34  USA: General Motors CEO Mary Barra sat in front of a U.S. congressional committee yesterday and said sorry several thousand times. She also admitted that GM employees knew about the ignition switch defect 10 years ago, but did nothing.

35  USA: The FBI is now investigating several unnamed high-speed trading firms, saying they might be acting on inside information. If you ask me, the whole practice of high-speed trading, letting computers automatically buy and sell stocks, needs to be banned.

36  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: April 01: 41 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: About one year ago, Google announced they were going to kill Google Reader. Now if you don't know what RSS is, then I can't adequately explain to you why that day was tragic. I immediately spent the next few weeks and months testing every RSS reader under the sun to find a suitable replacement, and I'm proud to say that I have: NewsBlur. Without NewsBlur, this website, and my enjoyment of the internet, would simply not be be possible.

02  Airbnb: Starting this summer, they'll be paying San Francisco's 14% hotel tax.

03  Apple and Samsung: Yes, the two are in court again. No, I'm not going to provide daily coverage of the trial. But I will say this, Re/code has published the best article I've seen about the case. Well worth a read if you want to understand what's at stake, which products are contested, and which patents are being discussed.

04  Apple: Reuters says "Apple suppliers will begin mass producing displays as early as May for the next iPhone, expected to be launched this autumn, with a 4.7-inch screen likely to be produced first while a 5.5-inch version could be delayed, supply chain sources said."

05  Apple: These are allegedly the first images of the iPhone 6. Personally, I think the photos are BS, but enough people are talking about them that I feel I should let you make up your own mind.

06  Apple: They've officially announced TD-LTE variants of the iPad Air and iPad Mini. Translation: iPads that work with Chinese 4G LTE.

07  Canada: One year ago this month, Rehtaeh Parsons, age 17, killed herself because of online bullying. The outrage over her suicide made the Cyber Safety Act possible, which allows minors to seek police protection from bullies, bring bullies to court, and hold the parents of bullies responsible for their child's actions.

08  Google: The WSJ says YouTube is offering big ad buyers "audience guarantees", which is a fancy way of saying YouTube will now play your company's ad until a certain number of people have watched it.

09  HP: $57 million. That's how much money HP will have to hand over to settle a shareholder lawsuit over that silly time in the company's history when Apotheker said he wanted to get out of the PC business.

10  HTC: Rumor has it that HTC will launch a mini version of their flagship phone, the One M8, in May. Said phone will use the same premium materials, but it'll have a 4.5 inch screen, likely with a resolution of 720p instead of 1080p. No pics. No price.

11  Huawei: They've announced that they shipped 52 million smartphones in 2013, short of their goal of 60 million.

12  Intel: They dropped $740 million to buy 18% of Cloudera, a "Big Data" company.

13  Jawbone: They bought Playground.fm. Financial figures weren't mentioned. Playground.fm makes an iOS app that mines your Facebook and Spotify data to build what they call "human-powered radio".

14  Microsoft: Google slashed the price of their cloud services last week. Amazon reacted less than 24 hours later. Now it's Microsoft's turn.

15  Microsoft: Here is Satya Nadella's email announcing that Phil Spencer will take over XBOX and Stephen Elop will take over Microsoft Devices.

16  Motorola: They've updated the Moto X to include the newly mandated "Powered by Android" branding on the boot screen.

17  OKCupid: The incredibly popular online dating site OKCupid is throwing up a warning message to users accessing the site via Firefox. Why? Because Mozilla's new CEO, Brian Eich, once donated money to a political campaign seeking to ban gay marriage in California.

18  Oracle: They're now bigger than IBM, according to the analysts at Gartner. Microsoft is King of the Hill, with $65.7 billion in software revenue in 2013. Oracle did $29.6 billion. IBM did $29.1 billion. And SAP did $18.5 billion.

19  Pebble: Target is now selling the Pebble smartwatch in their brick and mortar stores.

20  Samsung: According to the experts at DisplayMate, who I trust, despite the fact their website is hideous, the Samsung Galaxy S5 has "the best performing smartphone display that we have ever tested."

21  Square: "Starting today, buyers can purchase goods and services on Square Market with Bitcoin." Coinbase will be their Bitcoin broker.

22  Twitter: The son of Viacom's CEO has left Google after 6.5 years with the company to become "Director of Commerce Partnerships" at Twitter.

23  Twitter: They bought two companies, Mesagraph (France) and SecondSync (UK), both of which will be used to better integrate Twitter into the television watching experience. Twitter will also "expanded their partnership with Kantar" to cover "the Nordics, Russia, parts of Africa and southeast Asia".

24  UK: Mohammed Khalid Jamil, age 34, ran a scam where he hired call center employees in India to call people using Windows machines, pose as Microsoft employees, tell them there was something wrong with their computer, and then charge them money to install free antivirus software. He now has to pay $41,000 in damages.

25  USA: The FCC has agreed to open up 100 MHz of spectrum in the 5 GHz band to improve WiFi performance.

26  USA: The FCC will auction off 65 MHz worth of spectrum in the AWS-3 band (1695-1710MHz, 1755-1780MHz, and 2155-2180MHz) at some point in the future to wireless operators. The exact date hasn't been decided yet.

27  USA: This four minute video shows what happens when police officers in Rialto, California are forced to wear video cameras that record their every interaction with the public. Turns out use of force drops by 60% and complaints against officers drops by 80%.

28  Vodafone: The wildly successful M-Pesa mobile payments service has come to Europe. Romania to be specific.

29  Yahoo!: Rumor has it they're going to drop $300 million on News Distribution Network. According to the WSJ, NDN is "a video syndication service that supplies newspapers and other Web publishers with clips about news, sports, politics and other topics." NDN has denied that talks are taking place.

The Real World

30  Brazil: 65% of 3,810 Brazilians surveyed by "a major Brazilian research institute" say a woman deserves to be attacked for wearing clothes that show off her body.

31  China: This 74 second video shows off "the world's largest aquarium", which has just opened in China's Guangdong province.

32  Germany: The Lufthansa strike, what are the numbers? Three day strike (April 02 to April 04). 3,800 flights canceled. 425,000 passengers affected.

33  Greece: Protesting in central Athens has been banned due to security reasons. EU finance ministers will be meeting in the Greek capital to sign off on yet another $11 billion loan. The country has successfully eliminated its deficit, but unemployment still stands at 27%.

34  Japan: Roughly 3,600 minke whales have been killed by the Japanese in Antarctica since 2005 under the guise of "scientific research". The United Nations International Court of Justice has ruled that Japan must stop conducting their "research" immediately.

35  Netherlands: An unnamed 22 year old woman had the top of her skull replaced at the University Medical Center of Utrecht. The procedure lasted 23 hours and is said to be the "first instance of a successful 3D printed cranium". Warning: The header image of this article is graphic.

36  UK: Researchers from the University College London, tracking the dietary habits of 65,226 people over seven years, have discovered that eating seven portions of fruits or vegetables a day can cut your "risk of death" by 42%. Drop the portion count to five and the cut to your risk of death falls to 36%. Note that a portion is considered 80 grams (3 ounces), so seven portions is 560 grams (1.3 pounds).

37  UK: The UK now has their own Cyber Defense task force. The team is called CERT (Computer Emergency Response Team), they'll be based out of London, and it'll be made up of 55 people. The government says $1.4 billion has been allocated to cyber defense, but they don't say how much was actually spent on CERT.

38  USA: Another day, another recall by General Motors. This new recall, over electronic power steering issues, is for 1.5 million cars, bringing the total number of cars recalled this year to 6.3 million. The situation is so bad that GM Chief Executive Mary Barra has been summoned by the government to explain what the hell is going on.

39  USA: Scientists at Duke University have created artificial muscles that can repair themselves. "It's the first time engineered muscle has been created that contracts as strongly as native neonatal [newborn] skeletal muscle." Note that they've done work on mice. Trials on humans aren't even on a timeline yet.

40  Venezuela: The death toll from the protests now stands at 39.

41  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: March 31: 45 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: About one year ago, Google announced they were going to kill Google Reader. Now if you don't know what RSS is, then I can't adequately explain to you why that day was tragic. I immediately spent the next few weeks and months testing every RSS reader under the sun to find a suitable replacement, and I'm proud to say that I have: NewsBlur. Without NewsBlur, this website, and my enjoyment of the internet, would simply not be be possible.

02  Alibaba: China's version of Amazon just bought a 10% stake in a company that operates shopping malls for $692 million.

03  AOL: The ISP turned content company is now pivoting, again, to become an advertising company. Oddly enough, when Google, an ad company, dabbles in content, we all scream in opposition, yet no one cares when it happens the other way around.

04  Apple: Jean-Claude Biver, President of Watches and Jewelry at LVMH (Louis Vuitton Moët Hennessy), has told the Financial Times that Apple has been trying to steal some of his employees. He "saw the emails personally".

05  Apps: App Annie and IDC have published a report on app monetization models. VentureBeat has the key highlights. Most eye opening data point: Less than 5% of developers report that more than 30% of their users have made in-app purchases, yet "freemium" games are how most companies make money.

06  BlackBerry: The CEO has come up with a brilliant plan to save the company: Resume manufacturing of a three year old phone.

07  DigiTimes: TSMC hasn't even launched their 20 nanometer chips yet, but apparently they're gearing up to enter volume production of 16 nanometer chips in early 2015.

08  Dropbox: It's confirmed. Dropbox bought Readmill. Price unknown. Readmill will be shutting down in July. What's a cloud storage company going to do with an eBook reader app? "Our expertise in reading, collaboration, and syncing across devices" will find a new home.

09  Facebook: Facebook Messenger for iOS now finally supports group chat.

10  Google: Android Police have found strings in the latest version of Google Now which suggest Google may soon launch a "remind me to pay my bills" feature. What's unknown is how exactly Google will mine your bills to generate said notifications.

11  Google: Handset makers that want access to the "blessed" version of Android, meaning Android with all of Google's services and access to the Play Store, will now be required to include the text "Powered by Android" on a phone's boot screen.

12  Google: They've updated the guidelines that developers must follow to get their apps into the Play Store. Quick summary: Stop being so damn sleazy.

13  HTC: The company's new flagship phone has two rear facing cameras, giving it the ability to let users refocus images after they were taken. How well does it stand up to Nokia's "ReFocus" Windows Phone app, which does the same thing, but via software? This entertaining five minute video answers that question. Spoiler: Nokia wins.

14  Journalism: "Twenty-one of the world's top-25 news organizations have been the target of likely state-sponsored hacking attacks, according to research by two Google security engineers."

15  Microsoft: After getting into hot water for reading a Hotmail user's email, Microsoft has said they will not do that again. Instead, they will consult with law enforcement officials the next time they suspect a crime has been committed.

16  Microsoft: They pulled a bunch of paid apps from the Windows Phone Store that were pretending to be official Google apps. The question here is how the hell were they approved in the first place?

17  Motorola: According to the analysts at Kantar Worldpanel ComTech, thanks to the Moto G, Motorola's market share in the UK went from practically 0% to 6% in less than half a year.

18  Motorola: There will be a ruggedized version of the Moto G called the "Moto G Forte". No word on price or ship date, and this picture isn't exactly stellar, but the source (@evleaks) is solid.

19  Mozilla: Half of the company's board members (three people) have resigned because the new CEO donated money to a political campaign to have gay marriage banned in California.

20  Nokia: The government of India has ordered a "special" audit of Nokia's books, a process that the WSJ says could take six months to complete. Both Microsoft and Nokia say this audit will not affect the planned acquisition, but you never know.

21  Oculus: Michael Abrash, Valve's Virtual Reality Expert, has left to join Oculus. Key quote from his "Hello World" blog post: "We're on the cusp of what I think is not The Next Big Platform, but rather simply The Final Platform – the platform to end all platforms – and the path here has been so improbable that I can only shake my head."

22  Patents: "On Monday, for the first time since 1981, the Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether software — or more precisely, computer-implemented inventions — can continue to be patented."

23  Samsung: The Galaxy S5 has a "baby crying detector". Put the phone next to your baby, and if it cries, it'll make your Galaxy Gear vibrate.

24  USA: On May 27th of this year, a trial will kick off to determine whether or not America's biggest tech companies colluded to keep tech workers' wages artificially low.

25  USA: Two Los Angeles television stations have successfully tested sharing one channel worth of spectrum. TV stations are currently being asked to voluntarily give up some of their spectrum, which will then be sold at auction in 2015 to wireless operators. The stations that agree to this will of course receive financial compensation.

26  Xiaomi: It took them 34 minutes to sell 100,000 units of their new phablet.

27  Xiaomi: The company's CEO says he wants to sell 100 million phones in 2015. Lenovo, the new owners of Motorola, have the exact same goal.

28  Yahoo!: Re/code is saying Yahoo! wants to launch a YouTube competitor and that the company is actively courting "YouTube stars". If everything goes to plan, we should see Yahoo!Tube "in the next few months".

The Real World

29  Australia: In the 1890s, it was believed that spending 30 hours inside the body of dead whale would cure you of rheumatism.

30  Australia: This is a long article about the techniques scientists are using to prevent shark attacks, including designing wetsuits that make surfers look like poisonous fish. But what are your actual chances of getting killed by a shark? "Lightning strikes, bee stings, and car accidents all pose far more of a threat."

31  Canada: Facial hair transplants are now a thing. This 68 second video explains the procedure, which takes 12 hours to perform and ranges in price from $5,000 to $15,000.

32  Italy: In a bid to curb excess spending, the government will be selling roughly 1,500 "non-essential cars". A list of the first 151 cars, which will go on auction on April 16th, has been published. Dozens of BMWs were on the list, as were nine Maseratis.

33  Korea: The North and the South have exchanged fire, not on land, but instead on a "disputed western sea border". No deaths have been reported, and the North is saying they gave the South warning, via fax, that they would be conducting military drills.

34  Space: After 31 months of being "asleep", the European-built Philae lander has been turned back on. Its mission is far from complete, however, with the final goal being to land on a comet in November. Note that this little guy is 655 million kilometers away from our planet.

35  Taiwan: First protestors occupied parliament. Then they occupied the government's headquarters. Now they've taken to the streets, 100,000 of them. Why? Because they want Taiwan to be far less reliant on China.

36  UK: In the 1350s, the black plague killed roughly 60% of the people living in London. Their bodies were dumped in a mass grave, but no one really knew where. Said grave has now been discovered.

37  UK: Scientists have found a genetic mutation that makes people more vulnerable to melanoma, a type of skin cancer. This will help in the early detection process, but the disease is still incredibly complex.

38  UK: Since April 2012, the UK has issued domestic workers from foreign countries something called "tied visas". Translation: You can come to this country, but you have to work for this one family, no matter how poorly they treat you, so tough luck if they treat you like a slave. Depressing Stat: 74% of domestic workers entering the UK with this new visa have faced psychological abuse versus 28% under the old visa program.

39  USA: General Motors is adding more than 824,000 cars to their most recent recall of 1.6 million cars. They've also stopped selling the "Chevrolet Cruze".

40  USA: Latest death toll figure from the Washington mudslide: 18. More importantly, the estimated number of people missing has fallen from 90 to 30.

41  Vatican: Two men were arrested for attempting to deposit $4.1 trillion worth of fake bonds at the Vatican Bank. No, that's not a typo.

42  Venezuela: The death toll from the protests now stands at 37.

43  World: One million people a year die from diseases spread by mosquitoes. This BBC article details five of those diseases, and advice on how to stay safe. Spoiler: Constantly spray yourself with insecticides.

44  World: The United Nations has published a report that contains "overwhelming" evidence that climate change is in fact taking place and that there are "severe, pervasive, and irreversible impacts" we should all be worrying about. But will the UN's work push policymakers to act?

45  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: March 28: 41 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: When you hear intranet, you think of clunky tools powered by SharePoint — essentially it's expensive software that doesn't work on your phone. Igloo is different, it's an intranet you'll actually like. It's built with modern, social tools to help you get work done on any device. Igloo made this special report to show you how they excel where SharePoint falls short.

02  Adidas: The German clothing company is installing "Wi-Fi equipped lounges and mobile charging points" in over 30 of their stores in an attempt to get 16-to-24 year olds to hang out there more often.

03  Amazon: The WSJ said Amazon will launch a free streaming media (video? music?) service. Amazon then issued a statement saying that's total BS.

04  Amazon: They're hosting a press conference on April 2nd, and everyone is expecting some sort of set-top-box. Note that Microsoft is holding a press conference the same day.

05  Apple: "Russian government officials have swapped their iPads for Samsung tablets to ensure tighter security, the telecoms minister told news agencies on Wednesday."

06  Bitcoin: Several apps have snuck into Google's Play Store that on the surface appear to be some silly game, but they're actually mining Bitcoins in the background. Sadly, phones have atrocious levels of compute power, and worst of all, they run on batteries, making these apps nearly useless.
