07  DigiTimes: "Microsoft has set an internal goal of increasing global Windows tablet shipments, including its Surface, in 2014 to 25 million units, five times the five million units shipped in 2013."

08  Dropbox: This hard drive in the sky company allegedly spent $8 million to buy a Berlin start-up that makes a pretty eBook reader app. Note how I said allegedly.

09  Europe: "European Union Trade Chief Karel De Gucht announced on Thursday the anti-dumping investigation against Chinese telecommunications equipment makers will not be pursued."

10  Facebook: Mark Zuckerbug wants to "build drones, satellites and lasers to deliver the internet to everyone." Good luck with that.

11  Garnter: They've published some predictions about 2014 and 2015 mobile device shipments. And by mobile device, I mean four different categories: "Traditional PCs", "Tablets", "Mobile Phones", and "Other Ultramobiles (Hybrid and Clamshell)". There's little new information in here, but if you're an analyst looking to see if your models aren't crazy, enjoy.

12  Japan Display: They've announced that they will begin shipping 5.5 inch 2560 x 1440 pixel panels for smartphones in volume in April. That's 538 pixels per inch. And in case you're wondering, they're using low-temperature poly-silicon (LTPS) technology.

13  Microsoft: Office for iPad, it's now out. You can view documents for free, but in order to create and edit documents, you need an Office 365 subscription. Office for Android phones and iPhones, it's now free too, and you do not need a subscription to view, edit, and create documents.

14  Microsoft: Within the new Office for iPad app, Microsoft is selling Office 365 subscriptions. That means yes, Apple is getting a 30% cut.

15  Mozilla: The company's employees are asking their new CEO to step down because of his views on homosexuals. Note that Brendan Eich, Mozilla's CEO, donated money to campaigns that wanted to have gay marriage banned in the U.S. state of California.

16  Samsung: They've unveiled some Bluetooth enabled lightbulbs. No prices or launch dates.

17  SensePost: Remember that drone I wrote about earlier this week, the one that can hack into your phone while it's flying above you? The BBC interviewed its creator, Glenn Wilkinson.

18  Sprint: "Sprint is in talks with Dish Network on a fixed wireless broadband partnership, the chairman of Sprint told Reuters on Thursday." So Sprint is going to deliver home broadband now?

19  Switzerland: The Swiss National Competence Center of Research will be holding the first "Olympics for bionic athletes" in October 2016. Think of the sports you already know and love, but with cyborgs.

20  Turkey: Along with Twitter, they've now banned YouTube too.

21  Twitter: "Twitter plans to release a mobile-advertising product in the next few weeks that will allow app-makers to encourage downloads of their software." Anything is better than the ads Twitter currently serves in their official app.

22  Twitter: Re/code is saying that Twitter is using access to their metrics as a form of leverage against television networks. Twitter wants said TV companies to only promote Twitter, not Facebook.

23  Twitter: They're partnering with Billboard to introduce a "Billboard Twitter Real-Time Chart" that will show the music being most talked about. Said chart should launch in May.

The Real World

24  China: Being gay in China "was illegal until 1997 and defined as a mental disorder until 2001".

25  North Korea: The United Nations is waving their finger at North Korea for test firing two ballistic missiles on Wednesday. No one really knows how, or if, the country will be punished.

26  Qatar: An American couple has been sentenced to jail for three years for allegedly starving their eight year old adopted daughter to death so they could harvest her internal organs.

27  UK: England's Chief Medical Officer, Dame Sally Davies: "I have long been concerned that being underweight is often portrayed as the ideal weight, particularly in the fashion industry, yet I am increasingly concerned that society may be normalizing being overweight." Translation: People are accepting that being fat is OK, and that's a problem.

28  UK: Researchers at the University of West England have developed a test that can detect whether or not you have bowel disease simply by the smell of your feces. In a trial involving 182 samples, their test was 76% accurate. Don't worry, humans don't do the actual smelling, it's an elaborate "gas chromatograph and a metal oxide sensor".

29  UK: The Authority for Television On Demand installed Nielsen Netview software on 45,000 computers and discovered that during the course of just one month, 23% of people had visited an adult site. Average time spent at an adult site, per month: 2.5 hours.

30  UK: Two people have been diagnosed with tuberculosis, which they contracted from their cat. This is quite rare, so there's no need to panic, but it's worth knowing that such a thing is possible.

31  USA: "The US Air Force has sacked nine mid-level nuclear commanders" over cheating on monthly proficiency tests. The case is still ongoing, and over 40+ lower ranked officers also face the boot. Let me stress this: These are the people in charge of America's nukes.

32  USA: Can the United States become one of world's largest suppliers of natural gas? This BBC article examines the issue, looking at what needs to happen first, which approvals need to be received, and how long it would realistically take for the export of gas to actually begin. Spoiler: "Between 2017 and 2019".

33  USA: Six million people have officially signed up for "Obamacare", failing to reach the goal of seven million the White House had set for themselves.

34  USA: Six trillion. That's the number of calories the 16 biggest food companies in the United States have removed from their products during the past five years due to cries over obesity.

35  USA: Walmart is suing Visa for $5 billion for fixing the price of transaction fees.

36  World: "Scientists have created the first synthetic chromosome for yeast in a landmark for biological engineering. The new chromosome, known as SynIII, involved designing and creating 273,871 base pairs of DNA." What's the goal of all this? To get yeast to produce just about any drug you want.

37  World: "The World Health Organization has declared its South East Asia region polio-free." Translation: 80% of the world is now polio-free.

38  World: Multiple universities have poured over data from North American and European cities that have passed laws against smoking in public and have discovered a 10% reduction in premature births and a 5% decline in children being born "very small". Said data set contained over 2.5 million births.

39  World: The United Nations has officially declared Russia's annexation of Crimea illegal. Not that it matters, you think Putin cares what the United Nations thinks?

40  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

41  One more thing: Tradition dictates I remind you Tab Dump via email exists on Friday.

item.title: March 27: 41 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: When you hear intranet, you think of clunky tools powered by SharePoint — essentially it's expensive software that doesn't work on your phone. Igloo is different, it's an intranet you'll actually like. It's built with modern, social tools to help you get work done on any device. Igloo made this special report to show you how they excel where SharePoint falls short.

02  Podcast: James Whatley and I recorded our weekly 30 minute mobile focused podcast this morning. We talked about the new HTC One (M8), Facebook buying Oculus, Intel buying Basis, Google Glass Ray-Bans, and Microsoft's two upcoming events, one of which is scheduled to take place today.

03  Alibaba: The world's largest e-commerce company has launched an "investment fund" where people can chip in to have a certain movie or television program made. Think Kickstarter, but purely for video.

04  Amazon: Yesterday, Google slashed the cost of their various cloud services. Today, Amazon is doing the same.

05  BlackBerry: They're suing Sebastien Marineau-Mes, former Senior Vice President of Software, for joining Apple, at least that's what the headlines say. The real story is that Sebastian's contract said he needed to give six months notice before leaving. He only gave two.

06  Google: Tickets for Google I/O (starts June 25th) are in such short supply that the company will randomly pick who will be allowed to buy them. Note: They're $900 a pop.

07  India: Mobile internet traffic in India is up 87% year over year. Traffic via 3G is up 146% year over year. Traffic over 2G (yes, 2G!) is up 59% year over year. In December 2013, a 3G user consumed 532 megabytes of data compared to 146 megabytes over 2G.

08  King: The company behind the game "Candy Crush" went public yesterday. Their stock tanked.

09  Klout: Someone bought them for $200 million. Because ... I don't know why.

10  Microsoft: "Microsoft and Dell have agreed to license each company's applicable intellectual property related to Android and Chrome OS devices and Xbox gaming consoles. Under the terms of the agreement, they agreed on royalties for Dell's products running the Android or Chrome platforms and on consideration to Dell for a license for Xbox gaming consoles." Wait, a Dell Xbox?

11  Microsoft: The company is expected to announce Office for iPad today. Mary Jo Foley says we'll also see something called "Microsoft Enterprise Mobility Suite", which is a tool businesses can use to manage iOS devices, Android devices, Windows devices, "and more".

12  New Zealand: Kim Dotcom has launched his own political party. It's called "The Internet Party". One of their goals is to introduce "a New Zealand-sponsored digital currency that is safe, secure, and encrypted."

13 Samsung: South Korea's largest mobile operator, SK Telecom, has started selling the Galaxy S5 today. The rest of the world has to wait until April 11th. Samsung is obviously pissed. Note that SK Telecom, and South Korea's other mobile operators, will not be allowed to sell phones between April 5th and May 19th because they've been punished for aggressively subsidizing the devices they offer.

14  Samsung: The company's next generation budget 7.0 inch tablet has leaked. Spoiler: It's a jumbo Galaxy S5.

15  Samsung: The Gear Fit, Samsung's smartwatch with a curved AMOLED screen the size of a stick of gum, doesn't run Tizen like the new Gear 2 or Gear 2 Neo. According to a Samsung SVP that spoke to CNET, it's a proprietary real time operating system specifically tuned for battery life.

16  Tablets: The analysts at Kantar have published several data points on U.S. tablet ownership. Here are the key figures: 53% of consumers interviewed in Q4 2013 said they will not buy a tablet in the next 12 months. 34% were unsure. Among those who are not planning to buy a tablet, 72% said that they are happy with their current laptop/PC, and 42% said they are just not interested.

17  Television: "A new study from Deloitte finds that teens and young twenty-somethings spend more time watching movies and television shows on their computers, smartphones, and tablets than they do on their TV screens." Sample size: 2,000 and U.S. only.

18  Twitter: It looks like Twitter might replace the "retweet" button with a "share" button, but this isn't official yet.

19  Twitter: You can now tag people in photos (10 max) and upload four photos at a time. Best of all, photos no longer count toward your 140 character limit.

20  Yahoo!: Yahoo! Japan wants to buy a Japanese ISP called eAccess from SoftBank for $3.2 billion. Sounds simple, right? Here's where it gets confusing: SoftBank owns 42.5% of Yahoo! Japan. So how does this work?

The Real World

21  Art: Remember the story of that guy in Germany who hid over 1,400 works of art stolen by the Nazis in his apartment? The BBC has been given exclusive access to the vault where 238 of the paintings are being held. Note that the recovered art is so valuable that the BBC can't say where the vault is located.

22  Belgium: $13.8 million was spent and 800 extra police officers were hired, all because the President of the United States came to town.

23  China: The Chinese government has just purchased $10 billion worth of airplanes from Airbus. "The order includes 27 long-haul A330s and 43 smaller A320 planes."

24  Malaysia: "A further 122 objects potentially from the missing Malaysian plane have been identified by satellite, the country's acting transport minister has said." Some of those objects are as long as 23 meters (75 feet).

25  North Korea: If you're a man, and you're attending university, then you're required, by decree of leader Kim Jong-un, to have the same haircut he does.

26  Space: An asteroid by the name of Chariklo has officially become the smallest object in our solar system to display a ring system (like the planet Saturn). What's amazing is that the asteroid has a diameter of just 250 kilometers (155 miles).

27  Space: The 300 kilogram European ExoMars rover will land on Mars in January 2019. Where exactly will it land? Scientists have begun the selection process, and an answer isn't expected to be announced until 2017.

28  UK: There's a bar in London that holds a different kind of singles night. Bags of t-shirts that people have worn for three days are given to potential suitors to waft. If you like someone's smell, you're matched with them.

29  Ukraine: The government has agreed to raise the price of gas by 50% in order to secure a $15 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund. The people of Ukraine are used to enjoying cheap gas thanks to government subsidies, but that's going to change come May 1st.

30  USA: Charlotte, North Carolina Mayor Patrick Cannon, age 47, accepted $48,000 worth of bribes from undercover FBI agents between February 2013 and February 2014. He just resigned.

31  USA: Doctors in Pittsburgh will soon be putting patients with extreme injuries in a state "suspended animation" so doctors can save them. In summary, all of a patient's blood will be pumped out and replaced with a cold saline solution that stops most cellular activity. Once the patient is done being operated on, they get their blood back. Welcome to the future.

32  USA: Katheryn Deprill, age 27, was abandoned in a Burger King fast food restaurant just hours after she was born. On March 2nd of this year, she started a Facebook campaign to try and find her mother. It worked.

33  USA: Oklahoma Judge Patricia Parrish has ruled that not disclosing the names of companies supplying chemicals used to execute prisoners is unconstitutional.

34  USA: Remember the Chicago train derailment? This 19 second video is what the security cameras saw. Spoiler: It's kind of scary.

35  USA: Scientists say the beaked whale is now the new champion of underwater diving. One of their readings showed a beaked whale going 2,992 meters deep and staying underwater for 137.5 minutes, beating the previous record of 2,388 meters and 120 minutes that was set by a southern elephant seal.

36  USA: Scientists studying the brain tissue of 22 (dead) children between the ages of 2 and 15 have come to the conclusion that autism is a disease that can be detected before a child is even born.

37  USA: The death toll from the Washington mudslide has reached 24. There are still 90 people missing.

38  Venezuela: The death toll from the protests has hit 35.

39  World: "Scientists from the UK and Switzerland have used very intense X-rays to film inside an insect's body as it flies." Fun Fact: Just 3% of the mass of a fly's muscles are used to "steer".

40  World: Amnesty International says 778 people were executed in 2013, up 15% compared to 2012. Sad Fact: America executed more people than Somalia. And China is number one.

41  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?

item.title: March 26: 46 tabs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Constantinescu
item.description:
Bits and Bytes

01  Sponsor: When you hear intranet, you think of clunky tools powered by SharePoint — essentially it's expensive software that doesn't work on your phone. Igloo is different, it's an intranet you'll actually like. It's built with modern, social tools to help you get work done on any device. Igloo made this special report to show you how they excel where SharePoint falls short.

02  Amazon: They've signed a deal that gives them the ability to buy a 4.2% stake in the UK's least popular delivery service, Yodel, for $14.4 million.

03  Apple: The WSJ published a piece on Greg Christie, one of the engineers responsible for the birth of the iPhone. Scott Forstall walked into Christie's office in 2004 and asked if he wanted in on project "Purple". The rest is history.

04  British Telecom: They signed an agreement with EE to power a potentially new consumer facing UK MVNO. More details are expected "later in the year".

05  China: Police have "detained 1,530 people in a crackdown on the use of fake telecommunication base stations to send spam text messages to mobile telephones." Over 2,600 fake base stations have been confiscated since February.

06  Clear Channel: 75,000 "out-of-home advertising sites" in 23 countries will start running either NFC, QR code, or SMS based campaigns come this June.

07  DigiTimes: "Apple will launch a large (around 12-inch) iPad in the second half of 2014, with Quanta Computer responsible for OEM production." This rumor refuses to die.

08  DigiTimes: The site's in-house analysts say 422 million smartphones will be sold in China this year, with 278 million (66%) of them being made by local smartphone makers.

09  Facebook: They bought Oculus, the company who makes that virtual reality headset that the press can't stop gushing over, for $2 billion ($400 million in cash and $1.6 billion in Facebook stock).

10  Google: According to The Information, the next version of Android will add a lot of business focused features in an attempt to sway the BlackBerry crowd. More importantly, Google wants to bring Samsung Knox-like features to the entire Android ecosystem.

11  Google: In order to better compete with Amazon's cloud services, Google has reduced the prices for their "various on-demand, pay-as-you-go services by 30-85%." Storage now costs $0.026 per gigabyte, down 68%.

12  Google: They're testing a way to make the newsletters that you don't want in your inbox even more annoying.

13  HP: Remember how I said HP was going to reveal their 3D printer strategy in June? Turns out Meg Whitman misspoke. She meant October.

14  HTC: They announced, and started selling, their 2014 flagship phone yesterday, the HTC One (M8). It has a 5.0 inch 1080p screen, it's 90% metal, but it has the same terrible camera as their 2013 flagship phone. Multiple sites have reviewed the device, but I recommend you read what The Verge and Pocketnow published and just call it a day.

15  HTC: This is the 30 second ad HTC will air in an attempt to convince people to buy their new phone. Spoiler: Blah Blah Blah.

16  HTC: Want an HTC One (M8), but don't like HTC's Android skin? HTC will gladly sell you a Google Play Edition version of the phone for $700.

17  Instagram: They now have 200 million users who use the service at least once a month. 50 million joined in the last six months.

18  Intel: Three weeks ago, rumors started circulating that Intel bought Basis, the company behind "the world's most advanced health tracker and web and mobile service." That acquisition is now official. Financial details weren't mentioned.

19  Journalism: The Pew Research Center has published their annual "State of the News Media" report. There are more data points in here than I know what to do with. My favorite: 53% of U.S. smartphone owners have used their device to watch a "news video".

20  King: The company behind Candy Crush will begin publicly trading on the New York Stock Exchange today.

21  LG: I've been using an LG G Flex since February 27th. I scribbled down some thoughts about it last night.

22  Microsoft: "Today we are announcing that Windows Azure will be renamed to Microsoft Azure, beginning April 3, 2014." Let's hope this is the beginning of the end of the marketing department's urge to stick the Windows brand on everything coming out of Redmond.

23  Microsoft: They donated the source code for MS DOS 1.1 and 2.0 and Word for Windows 1.1a to the Computer History Museum in Mountain View, California.

24  Minecraft: Moments after Facebook announced the Oculus acquisition, Markus Persson, the man behind Minecraft, said he no longer wants to work with Oculus because Facebook creeps him out.

25  Nokia: They're going to hold an event on April 2nd where it's expected they'll announce the Lumia 930 and Lumia 630.

26  NVIDIA: Remember the Shield, NVIDIA's failed attempt at creating an Android powered portable gaming system? It's now $199.

27  Sony: A lot of tech sites are reporting that Sony isn't interested in Android Wear. Sony sent out a tweet saying that's a BS rumor.

28  Spotify: They're giving U.S. college students a 50% discount on Spotify Premium for one year. That's $5 per month for all the music you can eat.

29  ZTE: They unveiled a 6.44 inch phone yesterday called the Nubia X6. It has top of the line everything, but there's no word as to whether or not it'll be sold outside of China.

The Real World

30  Australia: They stopped appointing titles of nobility (knights and dames) in 1986. That's going to change this year.

31  Canada: Doctors are telling women who just gave birth that they should lose all the weight they gained during their pregnancy within one year or face increased risks of diabetes and heart disease. If a woman doesn't lose the weight in that time, it's a "stronger predictor" she never will.

32  Canada: Some radio station in Canada, desperate for attention (mission accomplished!), decided to hold a vote: Should they give away $5,000 or burn it? 54% of people said burn it, so they did.

33  Denmark: Remember the zoo that killed that giraffe? They just killed four lions.

34  North Korea: They test fired two medium-range (1,000 kilometers) ballistic missiles. The type of missiles in question haven't been used since 2009. Why do this? To piss off not just South Korea, but the United States as well.

35  Russia: The takeover of Crimea has countless other countries scared. Which ones? The BBC lists 10 and their relationship with the former Soviet Union.

36  UK: 20.7% of the board room members of the UK's 100 biggest companies are women. That's up from 12.5% in 2011.

37  UK: Deaths due to liver disease have risen 40% between 2001 and 2012. Raw numbers: 7,841 to 10,948. Blame booze.

38  UK: Researchers studying more than 1,000 patients have discovered that when your doctor measures your blood pressure, it's higher than when a nurse measures your blood pressure. Why? Because most people get anxious when interacting with their doctor.

39  USA: "A BP refinery has spilled an undetermined amount of crude oil into Lake Michigan."

40  USA: 18,107. That's how many boxes of cookies Katie Francis sold in seven weeks. She now holds the record for U.S. Girl Scout cookie sales.

41  USA: The death toll from the Washington mudslide has hit 16. There are still 176 people missing.

42  USA: This article about American unemployment and the death of the American dream is full of data points. Here's the one stands out the most, to me at least: 37.1 weeks. That's the average amount of time it takes a person to find a job today. That figure was 11.8 weeks in 1950.

43  USA: Three secret service agents tasked with making sure the President of the United States is safe have been sent home because they were heavily intoxicated. "One was found drunk and passed out in the hallway of an Amsterdam hotel."

44  USA: What's going to be the hottest job in the computer industry during the next 10 years? According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, being an Information Security Worker, otherwise known as the person that prevents cyber attacks from taking place.

45  World: Seven million. That's how many people died in 2012 because of poor air quality according to the World Health Organization. Almost 6 million of those deaths were in South East Asia.

46  You've reached the end! If you enjoy Tab Dump, then why not become a supporter?
